pros: Excellent benefits, some co-workers are great, but I only saw one person who followed most phlebotomy procedures accurately, but he had OCPD which was a huge problem causing other to refuse to work with him. I gave two stars for their benefits, but this is one of the worst places I've ever worked due to co-workers lack of experience/training/or negligence.
cons: I've never worked for a company with so many poorly trained, incompetent, or confrontational co-workers: processing specimen under the wrong name 3X in 1 week +, using expired tubes, wrong order of draws, ignoring IV fluid build up under skin instead of in a vein. 14 employees on extended medical leave, same person calling out once a month. I've had 3 supervisors in 1 year, and none of them have been allowed to or voluntarily addressed any of the above issues. I have only been allowed 1 day off in over a year. Ever heard someone say, "The dog sensed your fear and that's why it bit you." No, the dog has a problem. This was my experience when I reported issues with a co-worker (the same issue occurred with everyone I've talked to) to my supervisor's manager. They promote/hire unqualified candidates, people with a long problem history, so don't expect your qualifications to factor in to your application.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Spokane, WA
pros: Providence is a big corporation. My job is protected because it is a union job and most jobs at Providence are not union. They do have an integrity line to anonymously tell when managers etc. are not following the core values.  Recently when the budget had problems, Providence reduced management jobs instead of core staff. The work environment is greatly influenced by who the manager is. There are departments that are wonderful to work in and ones that are not.
cons: I have worked there 33 years and like most businesses my retirement has been reduced.  Managers are caught in the middle often when the corporate leaders decide to down size or outsource. They often expect employees to do more than we have time for.  There are some leaders that look more at best practice than at least expensive which is good but you never know when that person will move on. The nursing service staffing levels have increased a little recently though it is still tight. By nursing service I mean all the people who do something directly with the patient. Recently WA state has required a certain level of RN's so Providence has cut back on all the other support employees, like NAC's, and even environmental and food services.

pros:
Just to note, I worked for the Digital Innovation Group - a small, startup-ish organization within the larger Providence family.

Plenty of fun, friendly people to work with.  The mission is great and presents a wonderful alternative to soulless ecommerce or "sharing economy" companies doing nothing of actual value.  Managers and hours are flexible.
cons:
The organization seems to have little idea what it's trying to accomplish.  Bigwigs from much higher in the Providence org (who come from a healthcare background and know nothing about developing software) were constantly pulling us in different directions and clearly had no idea what investments and tradeoffs are necessary in building functional software.  Squeaky wheel customers were frequently getting the grease, to the exclusion of building a better, more widely applicable product.  HR and current line-level managers seem intent on importing as many ex-Amazon employees as possible and clearly have the belief that however Amazon does things is the "correct" way.  

Executives within the DIG organization come off unintentionally as hucksters, with constant meaningless tech-jargon re: "disrupting" etc etc, and they lack any clearly defined (or at least explainable) vision.

job_title: Marketing and Communications Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros: The organization's 150-year Catholic heritage and mission and core values (respect, compassion, justice, excellence, stewardship) are taken seriously and understood by all, and are sources of pride and commitment.  Work/life balance is strong and without lots of over-night travel and pesky, unnecessary meetings.  PH&S is a very stable employer, rarely (if ever) in it's history having a significant layoff.  Overall, personnel are very friendly and get along well.  The benefits package is strong with several nice perks for full- or near-full time employees (i.e., free yearlong transit pass; free parking at most facilities; subsidized meals and pharmacy products etc.).
cons: Overall, the organization is too tight with the purse strings...pay increases are minimal and no bonuses; technology, productivity tools and office facilities and supplies are frequently far outdated; employee training programs and prof. development are on the cheap or denied; etc. etc.  Also, very slow to promote good/qualified talent and release the bad talent. The organization talks a lot about respecting diversity, but little evidence of ethnic diversity in visible management roles or recruitment efforts.  Top/down management culture means not being included at the decision-table when you should be and being relegated to an "implementer."; not to mention you're often made "accountable," but not often given proper authority.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Laguna Beach, CA
pros: Please keep in mind that the following review is for the LAGUNA BEACH Mission Campus, NOT the Mission Viejo Campus. I have been working as a per diem RN there for almost a year and I really enjoy it. I have worked for another large medical organization before, and this one is superior. Mission treats its employees well and there are so many wonderful opportunities for advancement and variety, especially if you are a nurse. I have only gotten cancelled twice. The managers and charge nurses are very nice. The behavioral health and chemical dependency unit are very interesting and educational places to work. They pay a float differential. They pay for your education such as BLS and ACLS, and they pay you for attending meetings. The organization is big on educating staff on the importance of patient perception and satisfaction. They emphasize compassion and caring, which is what health care is all about. The med-surg unit is also nice because it's relatively small and there is good team work going on.
cons: The biggest con is that there is NO resource nurse, at least during the shifts I work. No one can really cover your lunch break. They need to fix that big time. Also their computer system, Meditech, has some really big flaws. But I can't really complain because it works fairly well once you get used to its quirks. Pay is not the highest, but good enough. (I make more than $500 per shift).

review_title: Well-meaning employees but poorly run hospital
pros:
-fellow employees were generally friendly and hard-working, though politics could easily turn certain areas toxic very easily due to the small number of staff in each area
-approximately half of the physicians were competent and easy to work with - the other half were either rude, dangerous or a combination of the two
-mission-driven, willing to "go the extra mile" for patients without financial means to pay for hospitalization/medication
cons:
-insane turnover (especially for pharmacists and physicians). Management is desperate to retain any and all warm bodies, so there is no penalty for creating hostile work environments or being dangerously incompetent. Certain physicians are sent to peer review time and time again yet they continue to practice unrestricted. I have serious concerns about several employees ability to practice safely (physicians, pharmacists and nurses alike) - they come to Providence because they know they wouldn't be able to practice anywhere else.
-hospital was facing severe financial problems when I left with waste (especially in pharmacy)  occurring at staggering rates. Basics like hospital beds with electronic scales or having working A/C and heat in the pharmacy were not provided in favor of wasting money on other ideas that did not positively affect patient care or worker safety/comfort

pros:
Really strive to apply their wonderful Mission Statement.  Staff growth and and encouraged and suppored.  Education if in Health Care is supported with some financial incentives.  Clinical environments are always of the visually and environmentally pleasing and clinical equipment is alway topnotch and in adequate supply.
 Satisfaction depends so much on department management style in a system of this size.  There is an annual Job Satisfaction Survey that is sent to each employee annually and is anonymous.  After analysis, each manager is given their results/feedback, and I perceive that they are also given job improvement plans and expectations.  Positive results should be reflected n next years survey.
cons: For a company who's main product is the provision of Health Care Services and actually has a Health Plan branch, I found the benefit package to be rather pallid; High deductable, high copays especially for specialist and diagnostic services.  Employee contribution for their monthly premium is also more then one would hope for... especially because Providence Health Plan is part of the system.    Depending on your manager, you may find yourself stuck in your wage scale with increases based only on cost of living with a cap on the percentage each year of howmuch you may be given as a merit/performance raise... averages about 2-3 %...  So be sure you are happy with your starting wage because unless your job position is re-evaluated for grade, you scale may stay the same for years....

review_title: Don't expect to keep years of service with transfer
pros: Insurance benefits, pay, coworkers, location.
cons: You are just a number to anyone outside of your immediate clinic/department. I transferred from one of their associated "ministries" to Providence after almost 10 years of service, and they completely nuked my years of service. I was considered an "internal transfer" from one clinic to another, had my original (10 year) employee ID on my offer letter, can't transfer my 401k from my Swedish to Providence because we're "the same," didn't get new insurance cards because we're "the same," said they had to nuke my former profile to transfer me meaning I CAN'T work at my old facility per diem any more, and assigned me new employee ID number. They stripped my nearly 10 years of service and won't credit them to me because they say they're "separate entities." Well my pay check for the last 8 years has said "Providence batch" at this other entity. We had their HR, their insurance, their IT. In fact one of our it people got absorbed into Providence after the merge and got to keep his years of service. However no matter who I ask now they say they're separate entities. Doesn't make any sense. Completely depreciates my PTO accrual and 401k matching, not to mention just the overall recognition of working for an organization that long. I should at least get to keep years of service since Providence took us over 8 years ago. But no. Zero. I'm just another cog in the wheel. Just a number.

pros: The pay is appropriate for the area.
cons:
At Providence St. Vincent's you are treated like a number and floated all over the whole hospital so that the CNO can get her bonus to admit more patients. They do not protect employees from harassment in every form, and do not offer any support to staff. Don't even bother contacting the union because all they do is collect your dues and pander to the company. You have no voice, no say, no rights, and receive no respect. Providence will screw you over in a heart beat to save a few dollars. Payroll will not give you your raises unless you implicitly call them about it, and there have been several times when PTO time has been not recorded correctly. Lastly, the nepotism is so flagrant that people who are blatantly unqualified are brought in and those who have more education, experience, and professionalism are left behind while others climb the ladder. The cardiac ICU is unsafe, and I would recommend going to another facility when in need of advanced cardiac care. 
Just go work at OHSU, because having to pay the extra money in parking is worth being treated like a decent human being. The benefits at Providence are horrible, as well.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: Many of the people who work(ed) here are brilliant, compassionate people whose goal is to better serve the patients and providers of PSJH. When the focus is on patients, the work is meaningful and impactful, both personally and organizationally. Also, working hours are hilariously relaxed, with engineers and product folks typically spending well under 40 hours a week with "butts in chairs," although many do work from home, as well.
cons: An ongoing push to turn Digital Innovation into a profit center is drastically, and negatively, shifting focus from helping patients to selling product. Top resources are being dedicated to sales, executives are moving up the ranks, reorgs are happening every quarter, and under it all, the patient is forgotten. The turnover rate is silly, as the most mission-driven amongst us move to other positions and companies where we can actually generate the impact we intended when we started at PSJH. Reorgs and attrition have fundamentally altered the character of DIG. The vast majority of exec attention is spent on finding new profit centers, whether that's the venture capital component of Digital Innovation or trying to reinvent the wheel so it can be resold.

job_title: Environmental Service Aide in Spokane, WA
pros:
The pay is good for entry level work that doesn't require experience.
If you work the night shift and weekends you can make around $14 / hr on average (pretty good for being a maid essentially).

PTO builds up very fast

If you are full time the company provides good health insurance (if you're supplemental you're out of luck).
cons:
As a housekeeper you get treated like dirt by some of there medical staff (especially by doctors in the OR).  
The company puts way to much importance on getting things done quickly and doesn't hire enough people to do the job right.  As a result it is impossible to clean rooms properly (without getting written up for taking to long in the eyes of management) and many areas of the hospital don't get nearly the attention that they should.  This is frustrating for someone who takes pride in their job and wants to make sure that rooms are cleaned properly so that patients are not put at higher risk of infection.

There is a lot of drama in the hospital, in the Environment Services deptartment much of this is drama between different shifts (people are mad that the previous shift didn't get their stuff done etc. This is usually a result of not acknowledging that other shifts have their hands full also).

The workforce is unionized, so you have to join the union and have union fees taken out of your paycheck.

review_title: Friendly people but little directional momentum
pros: The people working at St. Joseph (Covenant) are some of the kindest, most thoughtful individuals I have ever met. The senior management cares about the employees and for the most part are all quite friendly. The front-line staff cares about patients a lot: I would frequently be called by nurses because of billing or equipment issues that would adversely affect the patient later down the road, and I could tell they truly cared about fighting for their patients. Even the CEO would take time to get to know everybody by name.
cons: People settle in Lubbock and don't move. This means that within Covenant, there is a substantial amount of gossip and long-term relationships (20+ years). Additionally, there's little room to move up within the industry. My largest issue was that the company seemed to be directionless for the longest period of time. We have tons of metrics, but I rarely saw any concrete plans to move us past "business as usual".

pros: St. Jude is an amazing place to work in the beginning.  The staff there is what really keeps a person working there even when everything else is awful.  They have a lot of certifications and are excellent at getting you to believe they put patients and staff first.
cons: Management is very self serving.  In the beginning they treat you like a star and a valuable employee but as time goes on and as newer, cheaper nurses start, you begin to get treated like dirt.  They demand countless hours of unnecessary education and training in addition to your regular work hours.   They want you to come in on days off for training.  Will write you up is training is eve 1 day late.  Another downfall is the pay.  This hospital pays less than most hospitals in the region.  Even for advanced degrees, you wont work here for the pay.  On the patient side, I've overheard nurses telling patients in the ER that they are faking their illness and telling them to leave.  On one occasion a patient did lave and went to another hospital and was admitted.  This hospital claims to be non-profit but profit is all they really care about.

review_title: Providence Health & Services Great place to work!
job_title: Systems Analyst II in Portland, OR
pros: Providence is focused on fulfilling their mission of providing excellent and quality health care for all, including the poor and vulnerable through the application of their core values, of respect, compassion, justice, excellence and stewardship. It is reflected throughout all departments including non-patient care areas. It is a pleasure to work for a company that fosters a work environment that encourages and supports excellence. Continuing education in your field of expertise is expected and funded up to $1500/yr. The benefit package is excellent. The collaboration opportunities amongst the Providence Oregon hospitals allows the best practice models to be spread and shared regionally. The brightest and best work for Providence! It's a great place to share and strengthen your areas of expertise and knowledge.
cons: In IT an employee who has a clinical background can earn more money than the non-clinical analyst even when the non-clinical analyst has much more advanced IT analytical skills. Very frustrating, especially if the clinician simply has a Bachelor's degree. Doesn't seem fair when they walk into the same position you've been doing for 5 years and they have no experience in it but are paid more money than you are.

pros: Few good coworkers/employees to work with who somehow have managed to stick it out despite the excessive workload and expectations.
cons: You will find yourself continually given more and more work without any thought as to how much work is too much work.  The pay does not match the amount and difficulty/expectations of work.  You will be underpaid and be continually asked to do more in less time.  There is a gossipy atmosphere amongst employees which creates an untrustworthy environment.  There is very little flexibility which hinders any kind work/life balance.  You will find that employees leave, are let go, or retire, but their positions will not be filled and then their workload will fall upon the remaining employees.  Expect to do the work of 2-3 people at any given time.  It does not appear to be the goal of management to care about the employees, they will say that they do, but in action they do not.

review_title: Wonderful for two years, bad for one, horrible for one.
pros: Good experience for interns to 'learn the field.'  Benefits were diminished when I was there, are not as good as they were.
cons: To only pay for 5 holidays a year is one of the lowest in town.  Why would a supposed Christian organization not consider Easter a holiday?  Work-Life balance was nearly impossible in the department I worked in, as you were expected to do whatever it took to get the work done if the census went up.  (In other words, work several hours a week off the clock).  To use the word 'leadership' to describe the management in my old department is overstating it.  They were bullies, quite comfortable with yelling at employees, doing illegal and unethical things to either fire someone or to 'convince' them to quit.  The idea was 'All of you people are expendable; you are SO lucky to be working at an organization as wonderful as Providence, so you had BETTER do what we say at all times, even when we contradict ourselves.  AND you'd better smile and LIKE it.'

pros: With a long-standing Mission to care for the poor and vulnerable, Providence Health & Services is a leader in promoting HEALTH...not just healthcare.  This company is on a journey to offer World-class solutions that focus, not only on today's health climate, but also potential issues that the future may hold.  For people who like challenging their thinking and taking intelligent risks, all while answering to a greater call, it is an exciting place to work.
cons: While I welcome the fresh perspectives that some of our new senior leaders bring (from outside of healthcare), I sometimes find their lack of interest in the past and their sole focus on the future to be a bit callous and concerning.  There are reasons why people resist change/transition.  In Bill Bridges' transition theory, he contends that, until someone can let go of the past (emotionally), it is nearly impossible for him/her to venture into the future.  That said, these same leaders, mentioned in the first sentence, are offering some exciting possibilities and I'm looking forward to being a part of bringing them to life.

pros: Providence truly lives out its mission and values on a daily basis.  It has a long-standing history of caring for people in need regardless of their income level.  Providence is very adept at rapid change to stay in the forefront of medical advances.  We have modern equipment and we are given opportunities for ongoing education to be certain that we can provide the best possible care.  There is a sense of energy and focus in looking to the future of healthcare to determine the best way forward for the organization as a whole as well as the individual facilities and their unique positions in their communities.
cons: Sometimes the changes are so rapid and the organization is expanding so fast that it is hard to keep up with everything that is going on.  It can be easy to be overwhelmed by the many levels of organization both above and below any individual employee.  It can seem difficult to get attention to the local issues because so much focus is on the organization as a whole.

review_title: St Joseph is a very good place to work, but it has many areas to improve on before it can become a great place to work.
pros: St Joseph does a very good job of holding true to its core values.  Employees are for the most part treated fairly and feel like they are contributing to the greater good of society.  Furthermore, employment at St Joseph is quite stable (the organization appears to try to avoid layoffs at all costs), and fosters a strong work life balance.
cons:
St Joseph’s organizational structure does not lend itself to very effective communication between locations or business units.  This lack of communication has helped foster the implementation of quite a few duplicative/conflicting business processes, and the formation of rigid organizational silos.

In addition to limited communication, St Joseph—as a whole—is fairly averse to change, with Senior Management appearing reluctant to stand up to ministry requests that are contrary to the greater good.  This results in projects taking much longer to complete (and becoming overly complex to operate) than they would at other organizations.

review_title: Good benefits, but watch out for the middle management.
pros: The benefits for employees were very competitive based on what I've been offered elsewhere, or what friends and family tell me they have provided by their employers.  Also, there are many wonderful employees, providing excellent patient care.
cons: The middle managers in many departments seem to only care about how they look to Admin.  Providence management overall makes a big deal about listening to employee feedback, but nothing really ever made a difference in my department.  Our direct manager would ask for our opinions, then do exactly as she desired anyway, even when everyone under her presented a mostly united front for or against some proposed change.  Most of the managers there do not actually have to do the job task they now oversee and have no idea anymore what direct patient care is actually like, even though they make the decisions about best care practices and staffing levels.

review_title: Employee for the past four years
pros: A large company, working with a lot of great coworkers, close to home, a steady paycheck, mostly fair compensation and benefits.
cons: A large company, lots of bureaucracy, takes a long time to make even the simplest changes, high turnover due to unsatisfied employees and very low morale, management not forthcoming with policy changes and then penalizes workers (sometimes by name for the entire department to see) who do things incorrectly because of lack of training or policy changes. Very complicated policies, creates a bureaucratic hassle for patients instead of "easing their way" as the company claims.  Sets their employees up for failure.  Our managers have no accountability, employees have no higher ups to plead with.  No where to move on to without being certified in something, no in-house training.

pros: Co-workers are mostly great to work with as there are ones you can count on to pitch in for the greater good and not in it just for themselves but are part of a team.
cons: Lots of change going on and expecting to do more with less.  Long hours in some departments has become the expectation.  No assistance from Senior Management.  Senior Management  talk a lot on mission and values but many don't adhere to them but expect the staff to.  Senior Management (organization and department level) try to spin things to put positive light on it but only sounds untrustworthy for those who know the facts..  Raises are minimal but only Senior Management is entitled to bonuses.

pros: Helped fine a desire job
cons: Time spend in search and app

review_title: I have been in the same position for over 10 years and am staring to look for a change within the hospital.
pros: It's a good Hospital with mostly caring people working here. For the area the pay is OK and the benefits are almost unbeatable. Of course when you work at a hospital, you expect good health insurance. But the other benefits are good also excellent PTO/vacation  hours.A good support system if you are careful how you use it. I do work with mostly great people in my department and most of us who stay over a year stay for good. I have just begun to look at other other possibilities within the hospital because I'm tired of doing the same thing for over 10 years and would like to try my skills in another role.
cons: On the other hand  the policies of open communication are like politics anywhere-the policy states that there will not be repercussions for speaking out but it really is not true. Of course it depends on your department and your intermediate management. In my department there are a few positions that no one wants and so they are revolving door positions.

pros: Mission driven with good benefits
cons: Matrix organization and difficult to navigate

pros: Most roles have more than one opportunity for advancement/promotion. Changes are being made that focus on patient, as well as employee satisfaction. Team oriented atmosphere. Most employees are very focused on the mission of ensuring all are cared for in our system. Organization is continuing to grow, with a heavy emphasis on healthcare technologies and ensuring that Providence is on the cutting edge. A lot of brainpower on all of the teams. Passionate and caring employees. Management allows you to work autonomously and make your own business decisions, but are supportive when needed. Good mentoring, but they also listen to, and are interested in, employee feedback. I have no fear about speaking honestly in regards to any concerns or issues I may be having. Yes, things can move slowly or require multiple levels of approval, but this is typical of a very large organization. The good here outweighs any negative by miles.
cons: Holiday/vacation/PTO is one of the worst in terms of amount of days offered (18, and you have to use PTO for any holidays, not just vacation). Within corporate, you need to offer more flexible scheduling options for employees.

pros: positive outlook with team work
cons: not the best benefits provided

pros: Non Profit, Location, Flexibility, Schedule
cons: Leadership, Comp, Opportunity for Advancement

review_title: Highly political, good ol' boys club
pros: No lack of work here
cons: IS Project managers should be allowed to be advocates for their business customers but because they report up through IS they are expected to cover up issues and wait for them to work themselves out. It's seen to be more palatable that a project manager be run over by the bus then an application analyst or system engineer as an example. It's been demonstrated that management tolerates disrepectful behavior towards project managers (i.e. cursing, hanging up on). Project managers are the scape goats at this company. Also, the good ol' boys club exists here and the female leadership demonstrate the Queen Bee syndrome. I was once told by a female leader that to be respected and valued I needed to say as little as possible to convey my message because that is how men communicate.

pros: Core Values and Mission are a welcome part of the culture. Leadership is very supportive of Epic team. Many opportunities for cross application collaboration and mentorship. Excellent project managers, implementation managers/directors, clinical informatics and business analysts that contribute to team's success. Excellent change control and governance process for build changes in place. Many opportunities for growth with deployment, new module implementations (Phoenix, Cupid, Welcome) and ongoing optimization work. The variety of work helps to increase analyst skills. Continuing education is a priority with opportunities for Epic certifications and proficiencies. New review process for 2015 included a process for personal and professional development and an outlined plan to achieve those goals. New Career Development Opportunity: They created a new job role this year Epic Principal Analyst.
cons: There are 3 pillars on the Epic Team: production support, optimization and deployment. Some analysts have complained they don't get an opportunity to move to another pillar frequently enough.

pros: Reputable Company with high aspirations for growth. Good quality staff that are knowledgeable and caring. Most of staff is very supportive toward each other and willing to give help when needed. Getting time off when needed is almost never an issue. Monthly self-scheduling policy. Charge nurses are "hands-on", very skilled, and there within seconds when called into a rapid response situation. Good rapport between MD's and RN's.
cons: Seems most of the downside started when this specific hospital became part of Providence  and no longer an independent hospital. (Believe me, I realize the bottom line is incredibly important. But it should NEVER be above patient safety. Management is very visible, but not truly available. Criticism is not accompanied by support or means by which to remedy problem. All staff members are not held to the same rules, standards, and expectations. (Favoritism is inevitable, but should not be so obvious.)

job_title: Patient Relations Coordinator in Medford, OR
pros: Creating my own schedule is so great! My supervisors are very eager to help us employees with our work-life balance. I feel that the entry-level pay was fair.
cons: There are only two positions that use the float scheduling format, Medical Assistant and Patient Relations Representative. I wish that I could maintain this type of scheduling in a hybrid role, with other positions incorporated. I think that pay raises should be open to discussion more than one time annually. Working in this role with so much patient contact, I get sick more often than I would otherwise. High-volume clinics are also very strenuous, so when floating it is necessary to remind coworkers who are permanent employees of that location that the learning curve for each clinic varies.  I think that there should be a higher pay scale to work in high-demand clinics. High stress + High patient contact = weakened immune system and sick more often. When you are sick, you make less money because you are at work less. I wish benefits were available to part-time employees, that would make this job perfect.

review_title: EPIC Credentialed Trainer for Multiple Go-Lives
job_title: Epic Credentialed Trainer Clin Docs in Renton, WA
pros: Compassion and ethical behavior are practiced by most on a day to day basis. My direct manager was great.  Caring, principled and smart.
cons:
Lack of planning and forward thinking by management consistently ends up in major disruption to the lives of the trainers who have been on the road teach EPIC for 2.5 years.  

Upper management lied to us on a couple of occasions.  During the interview I was offered full travel expenses.  After being hired I was told I would not get meals reimbursed. ( I had specifically asked about this during the interview.)  They had to change this after HR pointed out that we were hourly employees and certain laws applied to us....  but it took a couple of months.  They offered us the opportunity to apply full time positions,  giving a salary range.  Then after we apply, and are interviewed they tell us that we will come in at the bottom of the range.  That felt like a bait and switch.  I was not the only one who subsequently turned down the offer even though I was offered a promotion with it.

review_title: Too Big for their Britches Perhaps
pros: Upper management seems to be very sharp, but is not always focused on what goes on with the troops in the trenches. Patient care at the expense of their employees' health and well-being is their main focus...ALWAYS.  After all, patients bring in $$$ and employees just drain the coffers.
cons: Emphasis is placed on Providence's Core Values and work/life balance when employees are first hired.  Unfortunately, what employees learn is that this is a lot of lip service.  This organization has grown too large to monitor, enforce or encourage these important concepts.  I was amazed daily by how much employees get away with and only the most heinous of offenses are addressed.  It terrifies me to even thing about ever being a patient at any hospital because for all the horrible things I've witnessed at Providence, I know they are still better than most hospitals.

pros: There are none for this horrid place of corruption
cons:
Does not honor union contract-I am owed 5 years of back pay plus interest and penalties.
Overworks certain employes while the favorites skate through not doing their assigned work. 
Allows racial, religious, and sexual discrimination.
Allows rampant sexual harassment and bullys and blames the one harassed.
Allows the patients to mistreat the staff.
Certain doctors are shockingly verbally abusive to the staff causing the staff- especially nursing- to abuse the patients.
Doctors never return their calls until too late. 
Does not honor education and higher credentials, only who has been there longer-Few managers have college degrees and 1/2 the staff do not know English on a high school level.
They are sending the nurses to a diploma mill so they can get fake Bachelors degrees in desperate attempt to pretend they have some educated people.
Hours are not given out fairly as managers allow their favorites to get OT while others get no hours at all. 
Never allows a way to get an uninterrupted lunch yet punishes the employee if they don't document one. They have been sued for this and lost.
Doctors so full of themselves they do not allow staff to call on other MDs for orders in an Emergency. 
Doctors so uptight even basic emergency care cannot be given w/o an order-but they never call back so the pt often dies or suffers immensely. 
Yeah a great place to work. Yeah a great place for patients-can you detect the sarcasm?

review_title: Great place to work and have a meaningful career
pros: At the top level, Providence makes a valiant effort to keep the mission, core values and vision at the core of why they do what they do, and still remain competitive. How that translates throughout the organization varies, but my experience has been outstanding. The people I work with are smart, forward thinking, diverse, and make it easy to come to work every day. I believe my managers are committed to my professional development. Compared to other places, work-life balance in my area is exceptionally good. They've hired some impressive executive leadership in Renton. It's too early to tell what kind of impact they will have, but so far, I've been impressed with their strategic plans and high expectations.
cons: The culture and expectations aren't consistent throughout the organization. There are some areas that are really very good and others that aren't. Centralizing operational management to Renton is upsetting some people's old local habits.

review_title: Disappointing experience after initial high hopes
pros: Good benefits, educational opportunities, decent pay, adequate training and equipment, some very nice people.
cons: Inconsistency in quality of managers, ranging from the Good, to the Bad, to the Ugly.  Middle managers are rarely scrutinized by higher management and get away with a lot.  Despite the general kindness displayed by most employees, there is an air of fear that permeates the company.  The work load is oppressive and most employees slack off on emails to compensate, making the response time on questions extremely slow.  The dedication to the mission statement is followed by many, but completely ignored by some key employees, including managers.  This is a blow to the general morale because most workers view this as the worst kind of hypocrisy.  There is a lot of lip service to high quality of work, but the reality is that the company is merely above average in this despite great energy expended toward improvement.  There is a dearth of joy or fun working there.  One must learn and understand the politics of this company if they want to survive.

pros: The company has a great group of people who truly care about caring for patients.  We have great people doing amazing things.
cons: What disappoints me is the number of reviews posted by providence recruiters who aren't truly reflecting the current state of the health systems.  Providence doesn't live up to its mission statement if you aren't in the hospitals.  The turnover is horrific, the pay is sub par, the hours are crazy and we are so busy affiliating (buying other health systems) it's a business and not a mission like they say.  I have been with providence a number of years and I am looking as with about 50% of the coworkers I know.  I used to love my job, but it's a sad place.  I hope that leadership some day realizes that the caregivers they call "employees"are people who have lives and problems and stress.  Take care of your people and they can better care for our patients.

review_title: Maybe choose a different health system to work for?

Also, my supervisor was great in teaching me the ropes and willing to give me opportunities to learn and grow.  There are many wonderful doctors and nurses who do care about their patients.

Also, willing to write up an employee despite the FMLA act and will call you while you are on leave.  Was called numerous times while on doctors orders to stay home.  Management willing to pass the buck.

job_title: IT Engineer in Santa Monica, CA
pros: Providence Saint John’s IT has improved in many ways since it was purchased by Providence.  Providence has shown that it is committed to being a leader in implementing technology to advance patient care throughout the system and did so aggressively in the two years after acquiring Saint John’s from Sisters of Charity (SOC).  Unlike SOC, Providence actually does a fairly good job of following its core principles with regards to how it treats its employees (caregivers).
cons: While Providence is committed to buying new technology and systems to improve patient care, implementation is a huge issue.   New systems appear to be evaluated in a vacuum with little input from IT and then dumped into IT’s lap for installation.  This incomplete and badly managed project plans, implementation issues (disasters in some cases), and unforeseen infrastructure impacts affecting other critical patient care systems.  Providence’s constant reorganizations leave caregivers in constant fear of being laid off, reducing overall morale.

review_title: A good place to work, The doctors are excellent and the staff good to work with, The hospital treats it's employees fair
pros: Excellent pt. to staff ratio 4:1, The benefits are excellent, and the wage more than adequate.  The hospital stands behind their employees. I like the 12 hr. shifts. I would much rather work 2-3 days a week than 4-5 days. They supply a good range of education that is free for the employees. and the upkeep/maintenance  of the hospital is good.
cons: If someone wanted to live near the hospital, Napa is a wealthy area (generally speaking) and the cost of living is higher than in many other places, I commute. The nurses recently voted  to go union.(California Nurses assoc.) It will take a lot before the benefits of belonging to a union outweigh the personal cost. Like all of the hospitals I have worked in you occasionally have to search for specific equipment (on night shift) but over all they have what you need available including a couple of amenities like a bladder scanner on the units. The hospital is a little bit heavy in the administrative staffing, But there is always enough staff to give good pt. care.

review_title: Good place to gain hospital experience.
pros: It feels like management cares about you, work life balance, benefits, reputable job, healthy food to eat, two breaks 15 min breaks and a 30 min lunch, nice coworkers in access services department, security, you work at a hospital in case you're hurt
cons: It's seems like there's a bit of racism that goes on, BORING, unfulfilling, the pay is low compared to other hospitals, too many meetings, management micromanages, being around sick/upset people all the time, management doesn't really listen to your ideas, old looking interior design, false promises of promotions or being able to move around, strained eyes from staring at a computer for 8 hours, same thing everyday, no discounts on meals anything your purchase from the hospital.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Spokane, WA
pros: Pay is decent benefits are fair work only 3 day a week some staff is amazing.
cons: You can’t ever speak up about anything with out being retaliated against. Management really doesn’t care about you unless you are a nurse. You do way more work then nurses and they get all the recognition for that work. A lot of fake-ness.

review_title: I love my job, it's my career.
pros: Friendly employees. Wonderful physicians and nurses. R.T. are the best. I have made friends with my co- workers, we are like family. I love how all the different units pull together for the best outcome for the patient.The health insurance is very affordable. The retirement plan is excellent. I like that we as the employees are asked to be on different committies asn we are able to have input in future plans.
cons: I wish we were allowed more sick days. Six days per year just isn't enough for parents of little children who get sick frequently, nor is it enough time if you have an elderly sick parent to take care of. I wish the nurse/patient ratio was lower, when we have five or six patients it becomes difficult to clock out on time without getting overtime, not to mention I think that it isn;t very safe.

review_title: The most sane senior management team in health care
pros: Very stable and very logical.  There is a lot of focus on the mission which is good but ultimately, it's all about business at Providence.  This is good since decisions are very logical and methodical. Providence also implements very well.  Right now they are still growing up from being a Portland HMO and figuring out what they want to be
cons: Since the company is still trying to grow up from being a Portland HMO, they are not realistic about new endeavors and resourcing them.  My main complaint is the lack of opportunity and movement.  Since they are lean, they really can't train anyone on a new position.  It's a very boomer culture where the expectation is that everyone stays at their job for 10 years and they seem shocked when someone wants new opportunity after being there for 4 years.

pros: PRMCE is a nice and challenging environment. The challenges of serving the community and meeting the business side is a constant push pull.  As an employee I feel heard especially around ideas and change. Going to work everyday is different and I feel like I am working towards the betterment of Snohomish County.  I appreciate shared decision making and being heard.
cons: This is hard work. As a manager you put in long days and many hours. Change is constant and this can be exhausting. Snohomish County is large with many social issues which is difficult to meet day to day. The resources in Snohomish County are limited and this makes our day to day job difficult. Communication is difficult regarding changes in PRMCE since it is a large hospital but they try their best.

pros: For such a large health system, I've been very impressed by the unified messaging at the system level that is communicated to everyone.  Despite our large size, I really feel like we are one connected organization.  Myself and my colleagues have  knowledge of, and support of the Providence Mission & Values... this is my first role in which this actually meant something!  This organization truly has the best of the best in regard to executive leadership both at the system and regional levels.  Leadership is supportive of you as a person, and they want you to succeed professionally.  I think the merger with St. Joseph Health will continue to bring together many best practices and great leaders to make the organization even stronger.
cons: Large health organizations have many advantages.... but working for them can also mean very slow processes to make anything happen.... sometimes feels like too much red tape and barriers.

review_title: My experience at Providence has been personally and professionally rewarding, creating many opportunities for growth.
job_title: Director of Nursing in Portland, OR
pros: The people of Providence are amazing. The mission is alive and palpable, with a culture of doing the right things for the right reasons.  Opportunities to advance education and grow professionally are available for those who seek them.
cons: In an effort to be fiscally responsible, there is constant push to do more with less. Leaders are asked to take on more and more, and support from senior leadership continually decreases as they are stretched thinner as well. Ultimately this is costly, as resolution to issues become slower and caregivers at the bedside lose access and relationships with their leaders. Because of this, employee engagement declines and managing staff becomes more challenging for front line leaders.

review_title: Employees are very polite and has great work ethic’s; One of orange county slowest rate for nurses salary

I was working there for 11 years the first half of the year was the happiest because the people are extremely nice polite respectful and since it’s a Catholic hospital devalue your concerns but the longer you stay there and you did not move up in your position you may technically might as well be worthless to them, I’m talking about the managers and the upper admin so if you’ve been there for 10 years and you haven’t move out from your position most of your colleagues have already been so it’s up to you if you could stay more on politics oriental workplace
cons: I’m talking about the managers and the upper admin so if you’ve been there for 10 years and you haven’t move out from your position most of your colleagues have already been so it’s up to you if you could stay more on politics oriental workplace

pros: Work load fairly predictable day in and day out. Steady work schedule.....standard bankers hours.
cons: There are so many cons I am not sure where to start. Since my time starting at this company I have worked under 5 different supervisors. There are so many changes performed internally that supervisors come and go because they fail to produce the unobtainable numbers expected from each department. My department has an extremely high turn-over rate, as people are either quitting or being fired for minuscule things. I have found incorrect data and untrue filed with my employee reviews. I have never worked for a company that treated their staff like 5 years olds and demean at meetings. If someone makes a complaint about you, it will end up as a warning directed at you instead of viewing actual facts. Worst company I've worked for!!!

pros: Not much to say honestly
cons: A lot of cons can’t name

pros:
I LOVED my job here.  I floated between Newberg, Portland West, and East with Portland West as my home base.  I worked here from 2012 to 2016.

Management: Supportive & Available. Easy to work with. 
Staff:  All disciplines worked cohesively
Unionized:  You will get paid overtime if you work more than 8 hours in one day.
No on call because Providence has an after hours line and nurses that cover from 5pm to 8am.  
Equipment:  Each RN gets her/his OWN accu check machine.  (I've been a places where you may have 1-2 machines for 5-6 nurses.)
Pay: Because I worked as PRN, I got $3 more per hour.  Even though, I was prn I wanted to work 3-4 days per week.  
Orientation: Organized.  You are with one nurse during orientation.
cons:
Compared to my other home health experiences, Providence was the best.  
I can't think of any cons.

pros:
Top leaders are driving change down to caregivers in a way never before appreciated. Because of rapid firing change, the organization has made great strides to improve the entire process. 

Our organization is seriously focusing on staff engagement at all levels -- they recognize happy workers create delighted customers, patients and physicians. This culture this past year has been far different than previous years.

The organization now provides reduced or free healthcare premiums for staff based upon federal poverty guidelines. This is a huge step in PHS creating healthier communities stating at home. 

We have a retirement plan with 100% funded by PHS. A 50% match for 403b. Match starts at 3% and goes up to 6% with years of service. 

Lots of perks thru LifeBalance program, phone service discounts etc.
cons:
Despite rapid change were are a still slow moving organization. We are working on agility & nimbleness, but it can be frustrating  at times. 

Not at leaders are on board yet with skills in what it takes to lead well and create an environment of positive energy and engagement.

pros:
Benefits - Decent with a great flex plan. 
Pay - Pay was good and competitive.
The people on the ground are awesome.  They care about patients and each other.
cons: Workload, training, support.  As a manager, I felt I had no direct training and no support from my leaders above me.  Games were being played and it didn't matter if you had a great track record.  If you can't play the games, it's not the place for you.  In fact, they encouraged bad behavior.   Instead of dealing with the root problem, they either moved the bad manager around or promoted them.  Nepotism is also an issue.  Favorites are made and if you can't be a favorite (despite your work history), you get let go for nothing you did or didn't do.  There is no fairness.

pros:
At Providence Holy Cross Medical Center in Mission Hills it's like working in a dream. I've worked in Post Partum for almost two years now and I couldn't be more elated. Management is wonderful and they're super flexible with my schedule. It was easy to go from per diem to full time to part time. Every staff member I've met from other CNAs to RNs to Houskeeping to the cook are absolute angels. It's easy to feel at home quick.
The work load is never too hard, even when I go to other units. Staffing will always try to float you instead of cancel your shift - but it's not uncommon to be flexed off if you want it. Management is always helpful and supportive of my continuing education. The patients are very kind and appreciative - many are Spanish speaking only so keep that in mind.
cons: Having to take annual Patient Safety classes/etc. (and now you can only take these classes at your designated hospital, you can't go to other Providence hospitals).

pros: Medical mission work opportunities are great.
cons: Management doesn’t follow their core values.

review_title: Dynamic organization, committed to the community
pros: People are here because they want to improve healthcare in America. Providence, Swedish, Kadlec, and PacMed each maintain their own brand & unique culture. Those in shared services functions (e.g. Finance, IT, HR) get to support multiple organizations and it's very similar to being in consulting as you're serving multiple groups and bringing forward best practices to each.
cons: The amount of change in the industry is unlike any other. For some, this can be an added level of stress as it's uncommon for private industry. Just when you think you have something figured out, it's very likely that the organization has decided (or was required by external forces like the Affordable Care Act) to go in a new direction.

job_title: Anticoagulation Clinic Registered Nurse in Everett, WA
pros: Some coworkers are very helpful and welcoming to the presence of new people.
cons: Most coworkers are not helpful nor welcoming; the aire of a clique is very strong and makes new employees feel uneasy.  There is no independent thought or work encourages -- management is unwavering from what they think is "the best way," regardless of whether you can show with definitive proof where improvements or changes need to be made.  Protocols are relied upon heavily; however, they are not updated when things changes, leaving employees at legal risk.  The medical hierarchy is encouraged and the delineation of roles is reinforced continuously; thus, teamwork is lacking because everything is always someone else's responsibility.

review_title: Good cohort of people you actually work with; management team ruins the environment
pros: Great place to gain experience as Nurse, Aids, Respiratory Therapists, OT, PT, ETC. Friendly environment, great community. Decent health and retirement benefit- not the best, but adequate.
cons:
The Nurses won union representation but it has not been implenmented; plus the union only covers the nurses- leaving everyone else to fend for themselves. 
Management cares only about the bottomline: claims there is no money for staff and overtime- spends lavish amount of money on superficial things ie. new carpet for the whole hospital and constantly remodeling the building- without actually improving infrastructor and work flow.
Relative low pay to other great medical centers in the area.
Heavy work load with low pay means high turnover rate.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mission Hills, CA
pros: Knowledgeable peers who are fun and close and succeed without management. Long term employees dedicated to the patient and making the hospital what it is.  We make the grade!  Unfortunately many staff stay because they need their jobs and love the patients and our friends are here.
cons: Administration is very dishonest, makes false promises, lazy and are not invested in their employees.   They are top heavy with many who do not know their roles and often micro-manage. They continue to overlook staff that should be promoted unless desperate.    They encourage and create triangulation.  You're very lucky if your a favorite but if not, move on.  They take your office away and let them be ruined down but their offices are beautiful.

review_title: Providence Health and Services  is ruining everything.
pros:
Great benefits - EAP, 401k, medical, dental, legal, life, short-term disability, tuition reimbursement, wellness, etc.
Positive culture, respectful, values-based
Always evolving healthcare, innovative
Takes best practices
Yearly reviews and raises, based on company performance 
Lots of training available
Ministries used to work alone, but after ACA it was cool to see the organization evolve and work together as one unit to expand services for patients. 
Rates best places to work in OC
Great employee wellness program
Lots of benefits
cons:
Everything was amazing, and the we were acquired by Providence (not a merge like they said). Providence is restructuring, elimating jobs and positions. 
Too many meetings, not enough time to get work done.
Benefits are moving to be what Providence has, HRA and HSA. 
Providence is taking over executive and above leadership, which means middle management is left to worry what's going to happen to their departments and staff. 
Demanding and ever increasing  workloads causing high turnover, stress and burnout.

pros: If hired per diem they work well with your school schedule. I work every other weekend. The hospital has sixty beds with two floors. The hospital has a great reputation in their birthing center. I work in the med-surg unit. The staff is friendly but a bit cliquey. Most staff has been working there for twenty years, that should be a good sign (right?). If you become a full time employee they offer good benefits, pto, 401k, life insurance. The pay is great compared to other counties. Care Partners/Sitters start at $19 an hour plus overtime.
cons: The policies are not always followed and inconsistent. Very different from most of the other hospitals I've worked at. They are currently breaking ties with St. Joesph Health System. The hospital is being leased rather than being sold and the 20 year lease just ended. This questions my     job security.

review_title: No Appreciation, No Respect & No Value For Most Recruiters
pros: Many of the recruiters were nice to work with and the hiring managers were not as difficult as some I've recruited for in the past.
cons: Lead Recruiters,  Managers have zero respect or genuine concern for front line recruiters.  Cliques are rampant and if they don't like you or you aren't part of the cool clique club, you become a worker bee with no room for growth.  They promote ONLY who they like, they give the most open requisitions to the recruiters they don't like.  You work hard hoping they will appreciate and value what you bring to the table but all you get is constant disrespect.  When I was there, some recruiters had over 125 open positions while others have 20!  Completely un-balanced and only based on who they liked or who whined about having too much work.  So many recruiters quit and it's only getting worse.  I would NEVER refer a friend or family member to work for Providence Recruiting / Talent Acquisition.

pros: When I started 20 years ago it was a great place to work!  You could see the values of the Sisters of St. Joseph daily.  It was great when one of the sisters came by the office.  The employees were appreciated and there were fun activities we did for the employees to thank them for the hard work we put in.
cons: As time went on and management changed the values of the organization weren't as important as when I started.  It was even told to me that the values didn't pertain to the worker bees, only management.  Once  St. Joseph "merged" (was taken over) by Providence Health Care everything started going down to tubes.  Employee no longer mattered, deadlines were changed and they start laying people off.  More people were laid off from California, Southern California than any of the Providence employees.  They are now in the process of moving many functions (Accounting and Accounts Payable) out of the country to save money but the CEO got a huge raise.  I'm so grateful that they laid me off a couple of years ago, it was a blessing for me.

pros: This is a large organization serving "the" mission of caring for the poor and vulnerable. As a relatively new employee here (one with VERY high expectations and standards), this company has impressed me from the early recruiting process to my first week on board. I was neither looking for a new job nor a relocation, and based on the "talk" but even moreso on the "walk" I said yes. 10 days in I am seeing the values DEMONSTRATED on a regular and daily basis at all levels within my team and broader functional area. Happy to report back regularly, but my overall, early assessments is "Exceeds my expectations."
cons: I think you have to be okay with a good amount of ambiguity and change. The industry is experience enormous shifts in response to consumer demand and financial / regulatory factors, and Providence is working hard and fast to get ahead of these and emerging challenges. It's not a "sit on the bench and watch" organization. We need everyone in the game.

review_title: Unsustainable workload.  Good Employees pick up the slack.
pros:
In this position, I met a lot of great people that I still keep in touch with outside of work.  

The overwhelming workload usually meant that the workdays went by quickly.

Providing assistance to the occasional patient that was grateful and thankful of the work you had performed on their behalf brought meaning and significance to the job.
cons: The workload was unsustainable.  During times when you would expect management to provide a helping hand, they were often nowhere to be found.  Both of these factors led to a high rate of turnover and considerable feelings of animosity from the staff.

pros: Opportunities, benefits, culture.... In all, I liked working here. I gained amazing experience, and met some of the most amazing people.
cons: As providence grows, their culture is changing. Although they still tout the mission and core values, It doesn't feel like they believe in them within their employee base like they did when I started.  When I started, there was a focus on work-life balance, and on treating all employees with as much love, care, and compassion as we do to the patients.  However, as Providence has grown and moved further and further from the founding Sisters, they are losing that compassion for their employees.

pros: Great co-workers and love my management staff. Pay is "okay" for  the work that is expected.  Nice that you can use your badge for food, pharmacy and gift store purchases.
cons: There are constant financial cutbacks.  Procedures change on a daily basis that end up affecting good patient care.  Lack of supplies due to distribution changes are a huge concern.  Management looks at the bottom line instead of listening to the employees.  Have never seen management (in other departments) actually DO the work so they have an understanding of what they are asking others to do.

review_title: Good organization focused on patient care -- very poor IT management
pros: Commitment to the mission to care for the poor. Most staff are there to make a difference with compassionate care. The motto of "Know me, care for me, ease my way" is important and supported by management. Good place for older IT staff looking for job security in an institutional organization supporting legacy EMR systems.
cons: Very fractured management across regions and affiliates. Poor morale and high turnover. Very poor IT services and Healthcare Intelligence management focusing more on politics and process hoops than delivering solutions. Very vendor-oriented with mostly outside solutions from consulting firms. Terrible environment for internal staff with technical or development experience.

review_title: EMPIRE of TOO MANY MIDDLE MANAGERS AND NO EMPLOYEE EMPOWERMENT
job_title: Senior Business Consultant in Renton, WA
pros: Very strong dedicated professionals in all areas of the organization.
cons: Providence is overrun with too many middle managers that clearly causes no employee empowerment or the ability to get things done quickly. The organization spends too much on duplication of roles from having a shared services office but has the same thing in their hospitals.  Money is spent with no thought or overall understanding running an enterprise organization, which in reality they are.   Rod Hochman drove Swedish into the ground; he has no clue how to run an enterprise organization...yes, the servant leadership is great but you have to live it daily not when it suits you.

review_title: Allow your employees to do their job in Accounts Payable.
pros: Good Parking in Renton.  Good Benefits.  Great Coworkers.    The company celebrates holidays, etc, but certain groups are not allowed to attend.  I can’t think of anything else.
cons: Management is a joke.  Spend more time in High School antics than managing.  Employees do everything possible to not include Manager so they can get work done.  Manager more interested in gossiping with favorites than managing.  A day the manager is not there is day where employees smile, work together and are able to get work accomplished.  Nothing is done about this and the employees are blamed.  A very Depressing environment.

review_title: Providence does not extend their mission statement to their employees.
job_title: Insurance A/R in Liberty Lake, WA
pros: The only time in my 14 year experience working for Providence that the employees were treated well, was when the department was outsourced and run by companies other than Providence.
cons: They do not treat their employees equally. They fire long time employees making more money, and keep employees making less, even if they are not meeting standard requirements to keep their jobs. They give too much power to leads, and management is not consistent with their employees. You are treated as a number, and work loads are manipulated to make it impossible to reach goals in order to keep your job. You don't know those that work around you, as you are unable to socialize in any capacity, even if you are asking work related questions.

review_title: Unorganized Reactionary For Profit Disguised As A Non Profit
pros: Good Coworkers And Parking Is Free
cons: Constant Budget Cuts And Pressure To Keep Costs Down Has Pretty Much Ruined This Place. It’s Run By Executives That Pay Themselves Millions On The Backs Of Underpaid Staff Who Are In Fear For Their Jobs. Layoffs Happen At Least Once A Year In The Hundreds. No One Knows Who To Go To For Answers To Questions. No Regard For Employees Well Being. The Mission Is To Help The Poor And The Vulnerable, Not Create More Poor And Vulnerable People! This Place Is A Joke. Think Twice Before Working Here, You Will Be Frustrated And Not Get Any Support From Upper Management Because They Are Too Busy Kissing The Rings Of The Multi Millionaire Executives. They Always Pay Lower Than Competitors And Can’t Keep Good Staff So The Place Is Full Of Mediocre Managers Mediocre Staff And Temps. I Wouldn’t Even Let Them Take Me To This Place If It Was An Emergency And I Was In A Ambulance. The Only Ones That Win Here Are The Ones That Keep Getting 8% Raises And Make Millions.  Today Another 1000 Employees Were Layed Off.

review_title: Mediocre experience overall - Worked for PHS since 2004
job_title: Office Administrative/Patient Relations/Business Office in Portland, OR
pros: I liked the Mission Statement and the "Core Values" were in alignment with my personal values. Benefits were good. Overall I could see the focus was for the patients.
cons: Management in clinics, lack of compassion (which is one of the core values), no rapport between team members,  poor compensation (I never made what I was worth, skills and experience) and annual raises are a joke at 1%!! - I was loaded with duties and tasks that I wasn't compensated for, and not properly trained to handle, stress was high everywhere at Providence (or so it seemed, I worked in about 4 different departments within 8yrs), I was looking for growth opportunities, proved to be very difficult even though they encourage hiring from within.

review_title: How it goes at St. Joe's...ems
pros:
-Coworkers are great people
-Pay is above average for comparable services in area
-Management actually listens and responds
-some benefits even for part-time
-Lots of overtime opportunities
-9-1-1/ Transfer/ interesting stand by
-not super busy 3-8 calls per shift avg.
-chance to practice alot of medicine... Go through entire protocols often. 
-good training and education opportunities. Education Dept will definitely advance your knowledge and training.
cons:
-if working pure transfer truck...can be true nightmare. Don't expect to see station at all every 4th or 5th shift
-average call takes two hours per call
-30 to 50 mile transports... 2am calls... Not fun. 
-very limited budget...old gear
-hamstrung management. EMS is kind of the step- child of the St. Josephs system. Alot of our needs go unheard - unmet by system management
-out of seven stations, 5 are shabby... Just random buildings or mobile homes with crazy parking that EMS was bequeathed. No real stations
-for a not-for-profit organization, there is alot of focus on billing.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Good benefits, Caregivers assistance programs, life balnace program, cell phone discounts. Patient care is wonderful, non mangment employees fantastic.Great mission Respect, Compassion, Justice, stewardship, Exellence.
cons: Newly hired management doesn't abide by core vauls  and/or Mission statement, Hr and some management  allows a hostile work environment, reporting behavior to management only gets the one who reports or attempts to report it fired.  staff is fired for asking simple question or sticking up for the injustices that have been going on. Coworkers some are good, but others just try and make your life hell if your not apart of the inner circle.

review_title: Wonderful mission and culture, but pay & benefits need work
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Portland, OR
pros: Wonderful mission, compassionate care teams, & a lot of opportunities for continued learning and growth
cons: Disorganized and confusing company structure,  & as of 2018 we all had to start participating in a difficult online health incentive program in order to earn money to put toward our health insurance.  The health insurance also has a high deductible, and the coverage doesn't kick in until you have met that deductible (of $1200). Since Providence is non-profit, their salaries are generally not as competitive as the other big hospitals in the area.

review_title: Providence is a mission driven organization with great healthcare professionals
pros: The mission is what makes Providence stand apart from other healthcare companies.  The staff are dedicated to their patients and the common commitment to core values and the quality of people who work here makes all the difference. Providence continues to serve our communities and those in need.  We have been humble about what we do as an organization.  The focus on innovation has brought a positive spotlight to the organization.
cons: The organization is growing faster than it's infrastructure.  With 73,000+ employees the organization is complex and seems slow to respond.  This can make some of the leaders feel distant and disconnected from day to day operations. I have the opportunity to work with some great leaders.  The systems and tools that need to be in place to support an organization of this size are slow to be implemented.

review_title: Unethical, tyrannical, dictatorial, and diabolical place for work
job_title: Registered Nurse ICU in Burbank, CA
pros: None at the moment. It was a good place to work where everyone practice all the core values.
cons:
Unsafe for patient. All nurses who complained regarding the safety of the patients being threatened to be fired. ICU RNs was forced to take more than 3 patients. 

No break time or lunch time provided. No relief nurses provided. When a nurse was not given a break time or did not clock out for break because there was nobody to relief the nurse, management wrote up the nurse and threatened the nurse to be fired. 

There are too many freelancer RNs who were not even qualified to take care of ICU patient. Many medications and procedure or paperwork errors were done and if it was not reported through UOR, management would make verbal harassment against that nurse.

This place did not hold its core values to the fullest. 

Pay sucks, human resource in cahoots with management to cut your years of experience. I have proofs.

In all very unsafe place to work and very toxic place to work.

review_title: I wish the nuns still controlled the company
pros: The company's stated mission and core values are noble; your job makes a difference in the lives of real people.  The culture in most areas of the company is refreshingly different than the corporate for-profit world. Generally speaking most folks are very kind and professional with one another. The flexible work hours are nice benefit.
cons: Compensation seems to always be lagging whereas the executives don't seem to have a problem getting raises, even during layoffs and pay freezes for the rest of the company, this didn't happen when the nuns (the Sisters) ran the Board of Directors. The executives seem to ignore the core values when it suits them. Every year they take a little more away from the benefits.

review_title: Steady decline in management behavior leading to extensive turnover
pros: Good benefits, fair pay, good work environment (physical), good coworkers.
cons: I worked for Providence Health System for many years with no complaints. After I transferred to the Portland, OR Health Plans division, things started changing. It started well, but over the years I saw unqualified people being promoted to management and even director positions. The managers were untrained and employee morale began declining. I left after a few years, realizing that it was going to continue to get worse. And it did...employees have either left or been fired in droves. We have begun calling this the "Providence way". They do not practice their core values of compassion and respect. It really is not an indicator of your value to be "fired" by Providence, just an indicator of their value as an employer, which is very low.

review_title: Has bitten off WAY more than it can chew in the last 4 years
job_title: IT Project Manager in Renton, WA
pros: Lots of good people with good hearts.
cons: Most all of the current management has NEVER run an organization as large as it is now and just do not have the talent or experience to do so.  Some very good people have left and who can blame them.  They try to keep the merged families happy but that just makes top heaviness and VERY unclear direction to rank and file staff.  Senior leaders push their inability to confront or settle issue with their peers down to the middle mgt. and senior staff level to fight out.  Lack of courage,  boo!

review_title: Beware of culture of overworking employees and because of revolving door
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Portland, OR
pros: Large organization that pays well and offers good benefits
cons: I had a horrible experience with my direct management team. There was a period earlier this year, when they were constantly making mistakes with my schedule, causing me to miss lunches, work hours on end without breaks, and work overtime. When I would complain to my superiors, they would try to fix it, but it would happen again. Then, they started quoting me my job description, which felt condescending. I went to HR who told me that doctors and nurses burnout all time at Providence and I should just expect to work without breaks and overtime if that's what my managers were asking me to do. Front-line employees are treated as expendables because they have a large HR department that can find another poor schmuck who will be lured into working here based upon the good salary and benefits they offer. I quickly started looking for a new job.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Santa Rosa, CA
pros: Working for St Joseph Health is not great nor is it terrible. They do provide a safe working environment and several days a month, the drug reps come in to provide us with lunch. They also offer an incentive exercise plan that you utilize on your phone to calculate your daily exercise and progress.
cons: Extremely low pay scale. Pennies for annual raises, very heavy work loads for Medical Assistants. When a coworker calls out, they do not have someone come in their place to cover, they expect the other MA's to absorb that extra work and this causes so much daily stress and resentment. There is no accountability to the staff that regularly call in sick, so as an MA you get burned out fast.

review_title: Great mission, good opportunity, changing values
job_title: Healthcare Intelligence Analyst in Renton, WA
pros: The mission: revealing God's love to all, especially the poor and vulnerable. Lower management engaged in, and very supportive of, employee work/life balance. Opportunity to advance. Mission related volunteer and service opportunities. Excellent compensation and benefits.
cons: Change fatigue. Workplaces being shuffled. Training cannot keep pace with changes. Corporate culture tending to reflect less faith-based values. Turnover seems to have increased. Leadership seems to think that the size of our organization, and the prominence of it and its leaders, is of great importance.

job_title: Systems Analyst in Lake Stevens, WA
pros: Local work environment is friendly, fair benefits, advancement opportunities are good. The IT group overall is very experienced and very helpful in getting tasks completed.
cons: Since the alliance with Swedish was made and an effort to consolidate IT support between 5 states, there has been a loss of communication and culture clashes between employees and direct reports. When you work at Providence/ Western Washington, have a supervisor at Swedish and a manager at Providence Oregon, I encountered a huge disconnect between employees and management resulting in my leaving Providence.

pros: Prov has great benefits.  I worked at St V so there was plenty of interesting clinical work.  EPIC is not optimized for pharmacists - so don't expect that but at least its EPIC.  There is some room to move up to within Prov so any job can help you get a foot in the door.  10 hour shifts are good. and PTO..  Everyone is good at there job - so you can rely on them.
cons: The in pt pharmacy at St v is very stressed.  They are constantly short staffed.  The patient to RPh ratio is high for clinical rah - but maybe that's normal?50/1 or so.... The long time employees are very negative so that can be hard to overcome.

review_title: I was very excited to work here given their mission and value statement, only to find it was only lip service.
