pros: Very good benefits, excellent pay, a lot of great people do work at providence.   Good work, life balance for some, depending on the department, for others a lot of overtime and weekend work.
cons: There is confusion in management, a tremendous amount of pressure to meet unrealistic goals.  This is translated into a tremendous amount of pressure on admin support, impossible to achieve agreement with calendar management.  30 to over 50 meetings per director per week is the norm. in addition to conference call and room scheduling, as well as travel that is constantly changing at the whim of upper management..

pros:
Live by their mission statement, and give their caregivers the tools and knowledge to live the mission statement as well. 

Limitless learning and growth through ongoing training programs and encouragement from every level of the company.

Extremely focused on work life balance which has in turn built a happier and more productive environment. 

Providence is an all-around warm and nurturing company that you can feel as soon as you walk in the door of any of the ministries. It is such a pleasure to come to work each day knowing you can come to work each day fully supported, and knowing that you leave having helped make a difference.
cons: Providence is a faith based company and though there is never pressure to live by their faith, it may not be right for someone who would find this uncomfortable.

review_title: I worked for the Health Plan
pros: It was a great company when I first started there many years ago.  The pay is good, the atmosphere is relaxed.  The parking was free and close to my home. There are many good employees there.
cons: Once you are there a long time, they find a way to get rid of you.  They know they can get someone in for a lot less money.  Many, many have been fired for bogus reasons that put in a lot of years with them.  The managers are awful.  Most of them have no idea what they are doing.  They won't promote you.  They have taken away so many benefits.  I guess because they have to pay for Providence Park now!

pros: Could goof off easily due to management's complete lack of interest
cons: Terrible management, idiotic coworkers, low pay, surprisingly LAME benefits despite many people thinking they are great...did I mention TERRIBLE MANAGEMENT?

pros: It was a privilege to work at Providence Newberg Medical Center! Its a pretty small hospital, which can be both a pro and a con, but I appreciated how everyone knew each other throughout all the departments. The care given to patients is excellent and hospital staff consistently receive positive feedback from annual patient surveys, I believe it was above 90% every year I was there. PNMC was the first "Baby Friendly" certified hospital in the state of Oregon. In addition, the building is a LEED certified facility with special parking for hybrid cars and charging stations for electric cars.
cons: I didn't like how there were no guaranteed hours for on-call employees, although I did know that when I was hired. They no longer offer extra pay incentive (time and a half) for working on short notice and/or picking up extra shifts, so at times it can be difficult to find coverage or people to come in when it gets busy.

review_title: Run as fast as you can!
pros: Great hard working employees....even if they are underpaid, and overworked.  The lower level employees still believe that the mission means something.
cons: There is no room for growth in this company, and if you do get a new job, the raise they give you laughable.  There is no way to get a raise, other than during your annual review, and the maximum you could get was does not even keep up with the cost of living.  But if you take a look at the Lund report, the executives are living a life of luxury. The benefits have become terrible in the last few years, and they even took a day of PTO away from their employees.  They take care of the community, but not their own employees.

review_title: Providence has provided me with a wide variety of nursing experiences to learn many new skills in 28 years.
job_title: STaff Registered Nurse in Everett, WA
pros: They have always paid fair salaries. And if you are smart and take advantage of opportunities to save your own money they will match a percentage of it. When I retired for the first time I walked away with almost half a million dollars.
cons: I have seen poor managers just moved around, not outright fired. It could be said that is good to give a person a second chance, But when it is the third and fourth time it is seen then these people need to be encouraged to see opportunities to work else where.

review_title: Great pay, Great benefits. Inexperienced managers.
job_title: Talent Acquisition Coordinator in Renton, WA
pros: I get paid well for my role, higher end of the industry average. Benefits are great and inexpensive. The high up leadership does a lot of employee recognition, for example free lunches/parties/barbecues. In my department, we have the option to work from home for 1 day a week.
cons: The management is inexperienced.  A lot of the time, education is valued over experience. My managers don't know how to delegate, coach, or deal with difficult issues, causing a lot of unnecessary errors because people aren't trained properly or notified when they don't meet the expectations of the recruiters. This leads to frustration for the employees who are left to pick up the slack in a VERY busy department. PTO is 15 days but that includes holidays, so you really get about half of that, which is ridiculous from a company so large.

pros: None i can think of!
cons: Since current CEO took over, he sold us out to Prov. Prov likes you to do the work of 5 people. Our benefits have drastically went down the tubes, benefits and moral. I have seriously injured myself on the job twice in 5 yrs, resulting in extensive recoveries. Had to hire a lawyer, because employer would not back me! After 10 yrs!! In 9 yrs, we have been through 8 managers! Providence not only puts their employees at risk, but also patient safety! Benefits are not good, employees over worked and patient safety jeopardized. Employees do not get proper breaks and are overworked. Resigning from my position was the best move! I will never work for another Providence owned company again! They only care about the bottom dollar, not patients or employees. Isn't healthcare suppose to be focused around caring for patients? Isn't this WHY we are in the healthcare field?

pros: I think Providence as a whole is an amazing company! I loved what the company offered me as an employee and had many great benefits as an employee!
cons: The Marianwood location is a mess. Employees were not heard by management and staffing ratios are ridiculous. May I add my schedule kept changing on me without notifying me? This happened three times and they weren’t flexible with switching days that I had appointments on. How am I suppose to have good work/ life balance if my work schedule keeps changing without me knowing? Then I get a call that I was suppose to be at work an hour ago and I’m not there. I wonder why I didn’t show up.... because nobody told me I was suppose to be there! I just felt dehumanized the entire time I was there

pros: When I first became ill, Providence was very helpful.  And they were pretty accommodating, too.
cons: As soon as they realized that I had a permanent medical condition, they disengaged from the situation.  All the support melted away.  The accommodations became less and less helpful.  The company they use to manage FMLA and other related accommodations badly mismanaged my case, which Providence expressed regret for, but which ultimately changed nothing.  They offered me no alternatives, and no other positions or options were ever provided.  I was forced to choose between my health, or my job.  If you choose to work for Providence, which, in good conscience, I cannot recommend, please be sure you are in good health, and have NO disabilities.  Regardless what a company claims as a policy, it's what they actually do that matters.  Providence doesn’t walk their talk.

job_title: Online Instructional Designer in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
There really is a focus on supporting and growing the individual. It begins with the language Providence uses- we are not called employees, we are called caregivers.

My manager is extremely supportive, allowing me the freedom to deliver my projects in the way I best see fit and the support when I need it, while holding me accountable for on-time delivery and high quality.
cons: Some of their technology throughout the system is old (although not mine) and we have to use SharePoint, Outlook, and Lync for communication and data sharing. Having worked within a Google-based system, it has been a hard adjustment to move backwards.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Federal Way, WA
pros: This was a friendly place to work, and there are advancing within the company. The benefits were also great. Once your earn trust, your manager will have you back. The standards expected is high, and there's a richness of activities and positivity and togetherness, old values of the sisterhood living on, and always new improvements which is great.
cons: As most nonprofits prepare to work very very hard, each position wearing multiple hats, and not receiving any or very little appreciation or increase in income for your extra work. You will really have to super to continue and advance. It's definitely a labor of love. However lack of funds is an issue for hiring enough staff, and upgrades on the very old building.

review_title: Working at Covenant as Staff RN
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Lubbock, TX
pros: Great benefits, salary, retirement package, lifestyle fitness center discounts, good cafeteria food, ability to use your badge to not only clock in and out, but access to door entry, parking garage, and food in cafeteria is billed to your employee account and comes out of your paycheck pre-taxed.
cons: Some employees who work there are very difficult to work with, and get away with workplace bullying. Terrible health insurance package, doesn't cover very well, is very expensive, and you must only go to a small network of providers, takes forever to get an appointment. Parking garages are very far away from the main hospitals, and even though there are security cameras, there have been incidents of people with criminal pasts, sexual predators, harassing employees in parking garages.

pros: Great co-workers, nice workplace physically, good benefits even though as part time I don't have access to all of them.  Able to offer discounts the other services if you are an employee.  Free Trimet pass.
cons: Pay is under the industry standard.  The reason you are given is that is a "not for Profit".  Departments do not communicate well with other departments.  People are hired over others not always for experience but due to who they know or are related to.  Brining in less experienced employees at a higher pay because they are a friend of a friend or their spouse has a high position in the company.

review_title: Does not support true diverse culture
job_title: Medical Office Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Good location, nothing else positive to say
cons: PEP in Seattle is a very clicky place. Was told I did not fit into office culture because my personality was not bubbly enough. Was only given 4 days to prove myself. Required a lot of training just to learn the clinic processes for scheduling patients. Made every effort to get to know other workers and patients in a small amount of time. Was always respectful, professional and helpful but was told that I did not chit chat with other workers enough. Permanent workers would talk about other workers, especially the temp receptionist, behind her back in a negative and derogatory way. Did not participate in that. Nothing bad about my efforts, skills, competency, and work were mentioned. Diversity is not respected. Diversity is more than just race, ethnicity, culture, but also about age, background, and disability. The personality criticism is hard to accept when one is an older worker, with Aspergers.

pros: The people are very collegial and the benefits are decent.  The Mission is inspiring.
cons: Management does not "walk the talk," and is very self oriented and out of touch.  Word on the street when I took the job years ago was that they exploit people via the attachment to and honoring of the mission.  They overwork you and pay you below market.  And they expect you to be happy to do so b/c the Mission is so compelling.  This has proven to be true.

review_title: Lack of support for growth and development
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Seattle, WA
pros: Great clients, some great co-workers, team approach, mission driven. For salaried employees time is flexible and supervisors are very accomodating.
cons: If you are working in a Providence facility or "ministry" as they call them, it's very hard to get promoted to the regional or corporate offices. In the facilities so many employees stay for so long---which can be good---however many of them are beyond burnt out and it seems the Providence way is that if someone is a problem in one department they just move them to another. Not much mentoring going on and not much building up of collegues.

pros:
-team camaraderie was excellent
-transparency in all areas of the Talent Acquisition department
-goals are customized for each Recruiter, with req. load, types of positions, etc.
-flexibility to work a schedule that fits you best, ability to work from home at least once per week
-beautiful campus with excellent gym, cafeteria and facilities
-compensation very good
-excellent benefits package (health coverage, PTO)
cons:
-the TA team is huge (over 80 Recruiters on Renton campus alone).  Not a lot of room for growth
-the company bit off more than they could chew when they hired over 70 additional TA professionals in Q2 2016.  Laid off many people in Q4 2016.
-Merger with St. Joseph provided many challenges

pros:
Most the Rank and File are friendly enough
Certain solidarity in trying times
A paycheck
Used to be much more family oriented with employees, since becoming Health and Services...not so much
cons: Executives will blow smoke up your backside talking about how the economy is creating all these "challenges" and how we need to be better stewards, sacrifice, all that typical stuff. Yet, when you find that a CEO in the organization can go from "earning" appx 3 million in 2010 then makes $6 million the next year, where's the sacrifice? Oh, it must be in the tried and true ransacking of the employee's medical benefits and salaries.

job_title: IT Technician in Apple Valley, CA
pros: Close to home, Great working environment, OK benefits. good PTO hours. Great team to work with. Has great work values. Provides good training and opportunity to attain more work related education.
cons: No holiday pay, all comes out of PTO. i.e. sick leave, vacation, holidays . Awards seem to go to the most visible employees instead of the more hard working employees.

review_title: Fast paced, rewarding, though full of distracted management.
pros: Patient safety is core to everything you do at Providence.  This aspect of working with them is highly motivational.  Providence is a religious organization with a long history (over 100 years) of providing services from a catholic perspective so don't expect family planning services any time soon.   That being said, the hospitals are well run and the new focus on elder care is a perfectly timed entry into an undeserved market with tight margins (clients with fixed incomes).  Away from the line of business (nearer the corporate offices in Renton) is where the political infighting frequently gets out of control. As long as you are a professional healthcare provider and avoid the management chain, you will find this to be a rewarding place to work.
cons: The management team is confrontational and distracted by infighting.

review_title: "A Positive Movement In the Right Direction"
pros: The company as a whole has made a HUGE change and it encourages all employees to participate in a team effort. Their purpose has become more relevant to healthcare and has spent money and time to improve its infrastucture  and functionality, so that it is a prominent name in healthcare.
cons: Management still has some things to improve on. The opportunities are still limited and promotional options are lacking. Policies need to be improvised. Some depts. need some help with improving employee satisfaction, which has to do with certain management personnel, who don't have the management skills necessary to perform the job.

pros:
Work like balance is amazing
love the free gym offered at the Renton campus
the medical plan is not the best but definitely out there, especially the no monthly premium and $700 free money given to employees to use towards that $1500 deductible
cons:
PTO is not up to market standards. We accumulate about 25 days a year but EVERYTHING, including sick time and holidays as well as vacations come out of that 25 days. Way below market standard.
Low wages, HOWEVER, it's all in how you negotiate (I learned this lesson the hard way). I've seen people get paid a $10K difference in salary for the same position

review_title: Find a better place to work
job_title: Strategic Management Services in Renton, WA
pros: All I can say is you'll gain experience.  Before you know it, you'll be doing 10% of what you were hired for and 90% of something else, or called, other duties as assigned.  There will never be a shortage of work for you if you are a hard worker
cons: You have to sue to get your benefits.  You're forced to do others people's work if you are a hard worker.  Their mission and core values are not worth the paper they are written on. If you are a person with any kind of health issues, don't plan on Providence Health and Services to take care of you if you suddenly become to ill to work.  In fact, they will deny you any benefits they can get away with. I had two heart attacks and arthritis so bad I couldn't walk or stand.  They denied me benefits and payments which is causing me to go bankrupt.  STAY AWAY

pros:
There are  a few decent managers out there but the majority of leadership does not represent the Providence mission in the slightest. 

Coworkers are the best because we are bonded over how hard we work and how the increasingly conservative corporate culture sucks the life out of us.
cons: Inexperienced management, high turnover, punishing and shaming disciplinary style, constantly understaffed yet demand more out of employees. When staff is unhappy and begins quitting, management reacts out of fear and tightens the reins even more which obviously creates more dissension and more resignations. Take a basic psychology course management.

review_title: Good work environment but too many leadership changes - lack of vision
pros: Good work/life balance. Providence truly cares about it's people. Health insurance has a high deductible, but is still far better than anything you can buy on the open market. Overall focus on health and well-being.
cons: Leadership reorgs have become commonplace. It feels like we change focus too often. The highest level has a vision, but as it trickles down, the execution is more disjointed. Technology is often behind, many laptops are 5-7 years old and frustrating to use. Many leaders worked their way up and are not fully qualified for the jobs they are in.

review_title: Good company mission and benefits, weak mid-level management
pros: Flexible work schedule, good benefits, good mission
cons: Pay (internal movement), workload, stress level high for corporate roles, weak leadership in mid-level (manager, director), corporate not adjusting to a merged footprint across multiple states.

pros: There are many opportunities for advancement for those who are motivated.  You can also find a role you like and stay there with no problems.  The organization is growing.
cons: Within the IS department there seems to be a huge departure from the original mission and core values that attracted me to the organization.  Outside of IS the mission still seems alive and there is a large group of people who have 15, 20, and even 30+ years with the company.  However, in IS this is no longer present.  Everyone seems miserable and there is always a constant fear of losing your job.  There have been 3 reorgs within a 2 year period.  It used to be that people were the last thing to go to save money.  Now it seems that is their first consideration.

pros:
- Most caregivers are good in their delivery of high quality patient care.
- Mission and Values are a strongly integrated part of every day work.
- Peer leaders and co-workers are generally supportive.
cons:
- Pay and benefits are at or near market, but not competitive.
- High turnover rates in both entry level and management. I know of a lot of leaders on the lookout for other jobs.
- Mantra "do more with less" means salaried employees work 60+ hours a week and little work-life balance here.
- It's a non-profit in terms of IRS status, but really just a big corporation with big silos.
- IT and some other departments have been through so many re-orgs and RIFs that they're rendered nearly useless.

review_title: Mission Matters at Providence - We All Agree
pros: It's Mission and the fact that the organization appears to try to embody it.
cons: It's a large organization and from time to time everyone feels like their corner of  it is neglected.  Supporting the cost of the bureaucratic infrastructure with revenues from providing services is a challenge - sometimes one wonders if centralized leadership staff know that the real mission is out in service areas - providing care.  And not all centralized functions are value added.

review_title: All Depends on Who's your Immediate Supervisor
pros: Good people, good value. The organization cares about their employees' health, gives cash incentives to be physically active and visits PCP annually. Depends on the which department you work for, the time can be flexible with great work/life balance. Management cares to hear employees' opinions.
cons: Don't expect large annual increase. 401k contribution match is low, PTO is slightly below average, confusing management structure, the organization is under going a lot of changes so there are lay offs, unclear what will happen with your position at this point. Hopefully things will settle down in early 2018.

review_title: Good first job in medical feel but no loyalty towards employees
pros: Team work was very prevalent once you proved your worth and that you could be trusted and accountable. Very busy and plenty of diversity in people and work. Most of the staff felt like good friends and family.
cons: Upper management and those who didn't work in the hospital or show up once in a while could be deceptive. They fought hard and dirty to keep the union out and targeted employees that were interested or just curious about what they could do ( this was about 7 years ago).

pros:
Strong leadership team targeting changes required for a healthcare institution to remain effective. 
Great co-workers.
Good healthcare benefits.
cons: Feels like the management team is throwing spaghetti at the wall to see what sticks - a bit of a panic approach as they try everything to increase healthcare profitability. Huge culture clash between business/tech people hired from outside healthcare, and the existing healthcare professionals who started in the industry to help people but don't understand basic business processes. Existing healthcare leadership struggles to build road maps/project plans/prioritzation that can actually be executed by team members. The repeated vague guidance leads to delivering products that don't meet the expectations of the customers. Current system-wide hiring freeze in place for new hires.

pros: Good place if you enjoy autonomy and you are self-driven. Management does not micro-manage but expects you to be independent and start initiatives. I enjoyed working with the majority of the departments and supporting them with their IT needs. The cafeteria food is not bad but can be a little expensive. Good PTO and salary.
cons: The only downside here, I question some of leadership management and senior executive team. The traffic in the area is a little crazy during rush hour.

pros: A lot of the employees have become very close, and it's a good sized hospital. Not too large, but also not cramped. They have done a lot of renovations to the main hospital in the last year or so. The manager I have is fantastic and motivating, which is probably one of the best things about working here.
cons: I work in a smaller department. Most of the employees have become complacent in their skills and don't work to sharpen up. I think most of this is because we are overworked and underpaid. For instance, they have needed to hire another person for about 6 months and it has yet to be done, so the rest of the staff has to divide up the work. Seeing too many patients per person along with dismal raises equals low morale.

review_title: Lab process broken at the organizational level
pros:
Multiple Lab systems are killing the organization and is making providers workflow unsafe. Lacks clear lab operational leadership to make decisions and standardize workflows that makes sense for the providers and patients. Lab management from multiple states have a very regional mindset and competing with each other instead of working as a team to make impactful changes for the clinical teams. Organizational decisions are made based on subset group of needs without considering full impacts. Continue to increase system complexity instead of streamlining workflows and decreasing administrative costs. 

The system also harbor lots of long timers who are not fit for their job, waiting for retirement.
cons: Great vision, lots of opportunities within the organization

job_title: Lead Business Analyst IT in Beaverton, OR
pros: The best reason to work is to just bag the money. Career wise in IT, this is not a place to grow because of old technology in IT. Most of the people especially developers working in the company are senior citizens. There is a lots of politics between these old people here at Beaverton and as a young guy, you will get bored to an extent that you wish to resign but you get stuck between these people for few months just because they get jealous of you WFH with the RSA token.
cons: Most of the Resource Managers and Project Managers don't have any college degrees. The environment is pretty slow and everybody talks with a ego just because somebody spread it around. Not that many educated people around here. Coders and Developers are all 50+ with zero coding skills and are grumpy all the time. Too much of Cheap  Politics on every level.

review_title: This company helped me become a better person
pros: High quality people and culture is based on integrity and respect. This company really lives their Mission and encourages every caregiver to take great care of their patient/customer, each other, and self. Work life balance is a priority.
cons: It's a huge company and growing larger - sometimes the red tape can slow down progress - because it's such a collaborative culture it can be frustrating to go thru meeting after meeting trying to gain buy-in from everyone. On the flip side there's a ton of innovation and exciting new change in the works.

pros: Best reasons to work at Providence is the people you work with.  I have worked in different departments and units and I can't say a bad thing about any of the people I have worked with.  Centrally located in Burbank, easy to get to from the freeways.
cons: From top to bottom, management seems to be on a different mission that what they want to project. They don't take suggestions.  Also, hospital security is HORRIBLE.  I don't want to say much more because I currently work there.  There are definitely times I have felt unsafe in situations with hostile patients or their families and I was told I was overreacting.

job_title: Senior Dietary Supervisor in Blue Springs, MO
pros: As senior dietary supervisor, I'm making the most I've ever made, but the other employees are difficult and at times it's like dealing with children. I work 11/12 in the afternoon to 8 at night which is a crappy schedule.. I get every other weekend off
cons: They hired me for full time and now I'm getting like 60/65 hours every two weeks.. I'm forced to use all of my PTO hours every payday to make a full two week check, so, I've been there two years without a single paid day off!

pros: Insurance coverage was great. Education opportunities great.
cons: My performance reviews were always "meets or exceeds expectations" But get a new manager who had no idea what she was doing who was very offended when I offered my help when she made a huge mistake that would have cost her, her job. From that point on she had it in for me. She sabotage me at every turn, and would even try to set me up to try to get me fired. She was very unprofessional. In her efforts to try to get me fired she put patients and co-workers at risk. Even after I left she went on a smear campaign to destroy my name to future employers. She is a very nasty person who brought a very bad name to the company.

job_title: Caregiver, CNA in Palos Heights, IL
pros: this company works on a christian work environment for all patients while they are going through their rehab and long term care. they also show compassion , love, support and understanding for everyone with or without family members while in getting the care they need. this company also support employees problems if needed with good communication . i worked for providence for 10yrs, and loved every day i worked i wish i would be able to come back or have the chance to become another employee for the company.
cons: this company is a very good company to work for while taking care of your family, if need a good place to take a family member this company would be the best to get the proper high professional care and rehabilitation needed.

job_title: Insurance Verification Specialist in Portland, OR
pros:
- Provides excellence health insurance options
- Has a great mission
- Cultivates genuine care for patients from the top down
- The Central Access Services department is developing amazing leaders
- Opportunities to learn and grow in the department
cons:
- As it is a large organization, it can be hard to navigate and seems siloed
- Parental leave is disability pay based and does not cover full wages/salary
- Some of the benefits were being replaced for worse options as I was leaving
- Due to budgeting and hiring practices set from above Central Access Services, our department was always understaffed.

job_title: Applications Systems Analyst in Renton, WA
pros: Came to Providence because of the Mission, Heritage and Core Values. Have met and collaborated with so many great people and personally have had some of the greatest managers to work with over the past 8 years. Have been provided with the opportunity to travel for work and believe we have great benefits (especially coming from 15+ years working for non-profits). Also, built great relationships and been promoted from within.
cons: Many outstanding key leaders who lived out the Providence Mission are no longer a part of the organization. Been challenging with much change throughout the organization.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Everett, WA
pros:
Paycheck
Helping patients is fulfilling
The mission statement
cons:
Management turnover is high
Lack of competent leadership
When a team doesn't like you, pack mentality pushes you out. Higher than average turnover. Can't keep floats around long enough to keep up with the turnover of regular employees.
Indirect complaints by fellow team members are usually miniscule compared to actual problems within the department; everyone will still complain about a team member anyway, even if it's a systemic problem then try to make him/her look bad. The deflection of negativity on to other individuals is commonplace, even though it is against Providence policies.

pros: The benefits package is great and the doctors I work with are wonderful.  It's never overwhelming and everyone in the office does their job.
cons: I spend a lot of time bored as there isn't a lot to do inbetween patients and my provider is somewhat slow.  The pay could be better.  I feel the sick time off restrictions could be better as I have only left early twice and never called in yet I have been written up for the two time I went home sick.  Also, management never seems to realize or tell you that you've done well.

review_title: Sacred Heart is a great place to work.  Always new experiences and new learning and supportive management
pros: Loved my boss and other OT's.  I worked with a friend of 30 years.  Lots of people have been there for a while and always teaching students and getting new therapists.  You can pick a specialty or you can be a generalist.
cons: It is huge and takes a lot of leg work to get from one end to the other.  Felt overwhelming at first, but got used to it.

review_title: Great mission and vision, struggling to unify organization
job_title: Marketing Communications Manager in Renton, WA
pros: The mission is powerful and motivating, to provide high-quality care for all, especially the poor and vulnerable. Providence is making great strides to shake up health care and use its size to help improve community health.
cons: Geographic regions of the company were allowed in the past to act like separate companies -- different polices, software, tons of redundant positions. Management is now trying to unify the shared services, adopt best practices systemwide and leverage economies of scale, but there is much resistance from the old guard. The HR department is a disaster.

job_title: A/R Specialist Medi-Cal in Portland, OR
pros: Providence Health & Services is the very best, did I mention very best employer I have ever worked for!  Their Mission, Integrity, Caring, Respetful among all employees.  They treat their employees just like they do their own family.  I can only compliment and say positive attributes about Providence Health & Services, I believe one of the very Best Healthcare Companies that people will see the change and preference when it comes to patient care, and they really care and give back to the community.
cons: Need Additional Staff to support the ongoing market.

review_title: Leaders not competent at some levels
pros: Flexible work schedule.  Sense of working for something greater due to its mission.
cons:
If you are ok with a "Lifestyle" job and you are OK with just being able to perform "ok" work then this may be the place fore you.  But, do not expect understanding for "excellence" which is supposed to be a core value of this organization.  They allow poor performers to stay in the organization and suck it dry of productivity.  The people who do perform well, get assigned more and more work, with little "sincere" recognition.

The Leaders are not competent at some levels and nothing is done about it.  So the employees suffer though the lack of clear direction and ability to command respect.

pros: Great people to work with.  Good work ethic apparent in most staff.  Excellent benefits.  Hourly pay.  Company values are excellent.  Lots of room for professional development.  Opportunities for education and classes in house.  I am new so there are some things that I don't know yet.  Faith based, Mission-driven organization.  In comparison to other companies, this one appears to have a better work life balance by a long shot.
cons: Time off requests have to be processed 6 months ahead of time.  But the management is working with me for achieving time off that I need.  One employee mentioned that the management didn't take employee input seriously, but I don't really sense that yet because we had a meeting where staff were asked specifically for their input.

pros: Providence is an organization that actually LIVES its mission and values.  Their actions every day show how much they care about their caregivers (everyone is a caregiver even if you don't directly care for patients) and their patients.  Our benefits are excellent and we are continually innovating and working to improve the health of our communities.  We are constantly reminded how important our families are and that it's our "whole life," not a work/life balance.  For the first time in a long time, I can bring my "whole self" to work - I don't have to leave a part of who I am at home.
cons: The only downside is the very fast-paced change that is happening.  It's exciting, but can also be a bit frustrating and confusing as things change so quickly.

pros: I feel that Sutter Health has the same Pro's that I have for my Patients that I care for. The Caring and going that Extra Mile for that Patient/Patients and their loved ones at that time of need in their Lives. This shows in the care and concern that I give to my patients and shows with the administrative decisions that are made by Sutter which makes us a strong caring healing organized Team.
cons: The only Con that I can see is that when I hear different complaints from coworkers that seem that they are not being heard from the administrative part of the (team).

review_title: Micromanagement at its finest. Taking away all Care Providers power to practice medicine safe and effective.
job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Central Point, OR
pros: Large multi-faceted system in over 5 states. Only work here if like to practice medicine in a small box where you are told how you will provide care on all levels and be picked apart piece by piece over every detail that they deem important .. Day after day -
cons: Large multi faceted system in over 5 states. Changes are global without investigating if all areas will benefit (and so often do not). Patients become numbers and Care Providers are micromanaged to death. It creates a culture of unhappy, overworked, under appreciated professionals that find little to no joy in their delivery of health care. They are dis-honest and do not follow their mission. When approached with concerns, they have people in power that force your silence or make it so unpleasant that you leave or they retaliate with threats.

review_title: Culture has changed, high turn over in middle management, longterm nurses leaving
pros: Great team of nurses/MSWs/Aids/Triage Staff/Schedulers work well together, daytime working hours although often with OT but they are day hours, occasional weekends or evening coverage
cons: No competitive pay with their own hospital pay, below market for other hospitals/services in the area, poor management, they have hired in micromanagers, managers with alterior motives and are toxic and due to this, the culture of the working environment has changed drastically and is having a negative effect on the organization as a whole, employees don't feel valued, employee who has dedicated many years of service to the organization and management makes the employees feel like we are easily replaceable

job_title: RN Home Health in Olympia, WA
pros: Great team of LPN, PT, OT, SLP and MSW.  Great benefits.  Most managers are supporting and reasonable especially in balancing the business side of healthcare with patient care and employee needs.  The company actually honors its mission of serving the poor and vulnerable and is putting more emphasis on employee orientation.  Hours can be long while staffing is inadequate but they are sparing no expense to fill open positions with great new clinicians.
cons: Some of the more senior staff are bitter and very negative.  Our agency is rebuilding which creates lots of change but seems to be moving in the right direction.  Pay is lower than competitors but dictated by union contract

pros: I love working at the Cancer Research Center (EACRI). I have been here for 2 and a half years and leadership is amazing, inspiring, and accessible; from my manager to the director of the cancer center. It's a relatively small research center, mostly focused on cancer immunotherapy, majority using mouse models and some working with clinical trials staff. There are plenty of engaging opportunities to learn from everyone in the department, we are encouraged to pursue further training and present our data in conferences. Benefits package is great
cons:
Not much vacation time, but we work together in our lab to accommodate everyone's schedules. 
Pay scale and hierarchy can be a little stiff, with not much juggling for those who are looking for new positions to be created based on needs.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in West Seattle, WA
pros: Free meal tickets once every great while.
cons:
They are all Union.
Union lawyers are shunned abd shut down when they are supporting employees who are innocent of any and all charges they may be brought against an employee just because they dont favor them above other employees. Providence Mount Saint Vincent tells the union attorney's that they cannot support the employees there and if they want to terminate them for No Reason, they are going to do it any way. My attorney apologized to me and said Innocence doesnt matter. They are terminating my employment because I made them wrong and they look bad now.
Providence Mount Saint Vincent thinks they are literally God. They are very Evil.
They even asked me " DO YOU THINK WE ARE EVIL"?  Just like the devil.
Of course I didnt answer them. They cornered me.  VERY BAD PLACE TO WORK.

review_title: Digital Innovation Group... Meh... it's ok
job_title: Senior Web Developer in Seattle, WA
pros:
Get to work on the latest technologies
Just implemented a bonus benefit
You can find a better place to work
cons:
The pay ranges: some people way underpaid some way overpaid (for what they do)
Feels like favoritism/nepotism type stuff going on: Good ol' boy networking here, promotions without the experience to back it up
Waterfall labelled as agile
Managers that are never there to lead the group they manage

pros:
- Good benefits
- Great co-workers
- Friendly work environment
- Good work/life balance
cons:
If you're passionate about making impact and contribution to the company's success, you'll be frustrated. If job satisfaction doesn't mean anything to you, this is a great company to work for. 
- Very top heavy: too many positions that cannot be justified
- Very few people doing the actual heavy lifting
- Too big for its own good
- Runs on inefficiencies
- Not willing to change
- Your voice will be ignored
- That of a very old organization(>100years)

pros:
Good health insurance. 
Good doctors within network. 
Many great people who work there.
cons:
Your experience at Providence is tied to what department you are in. There is no consistency across departments.  People who should not be in supervisor positions somehow manage to get them and keep them despite not being suited for the role and not completing their duties. 
The mission is talked about often yet is rarely practiced. It is used mostly as a crutch in order to excuse poor performance and lack of leadership. 
Keep in mind this was my experience in my department. I have heard wonderful things from other departments in the Providence family.

review_title: Ok place to work, Poor management,
pros: Ok place to work, nice co-worker and flexible time off and working hours.
cons:
Ok Benefits, It is a health care company,  but we have high deductible for our health care. 

Some years no merit increase, some year 0.25% and others years about the same not even 2%. Our vacation days got took away 4 days for people who work longer than 7 years once, already pay deduction. 
Company said that they have no profits, so no increase, but Upper management got Bonuses for non profit company? Company keep merging or buying  with other companies, mean they are growing, but no increase for lower level employees.

Act like non- profit, but all profits for upper management and CEO 😖

review_title: If everyone followed the mission values, it would be a wonderful place to work.
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Spokane, WA
pros: Wages are finally up to standard, for the longest time, they were subpar. Benefits are great. It's not a horrible place to work, as long as you can be emotionally void.
cons: Nothing is consistent from one manager to the next, from one employee to the next. Some get rewarded while others are not. Clinics are not uniform, yet it is supposed to be. It is hard to go from one clinic to the next without feeling unprepared. Yet, all is supposed to be the same practices.

review_title: Providence has done a good job in looking inviting to the new comer..
pros: The community of co-workers is a great environment with the opportunity to grow into different departments. I love the mission and what Providence does for the community, along with the different training's it provides to it's employees.
cons: Upper management tends to not be transparent in the decisions they are going to make, this makes for hard transitions between new team members and new leadership.Compensation tends to be a big issue as many are promised the ability to move up in their department, but it doesn't happen.

pros: When I first got hired on at Providence it felt like my second family. Great benefits, great people, culture and felt like I had a professional purpose that was actually helping people and not just another corporate company that made me feel like a number.
cons: When the company went through transformational changes and destroyed departments based on the bottom line and forgot to follow their own mission and values it created a very stressful, a unnerving place to work. Most people were talking about who got let go that week and wondering if they knew if they were going to have a job the following week.

job_title: Project Coordinator Administration in Seward, AK
pros: Started as an admin assistant when the economy took a down turn in construction where I used to work. For the first 2 years Providence not only worked with my school schedule, encouraged me to finish my BA but also provided financial support in pursuing my studies. If you are looking for a company where you can invest your time and get great returns via career opportunities look no further.
cons: As with all healthcare systems, change is here and although there have been restructuring in departments I work for the last 8 years, I have always grown in the new position and opportunities that are a result of the restructure. In a way these restructures have "pushed" me out of my comfort zone and allowed me to grow and prosper in new positions.

pros: Convenient location with respect to freeways, parking, lots of growth opportunity if you are willing to work for it and can handle a dysfunctional environment.
cons: Very uncollaborative environment.  Many leaders refuse to work positively with other departments and the line staff are caught in the crosshairs.  There are some emotionally abusive managers and those managers are not held accountable for their behavior or their turnover.  If anything, they seemed to be rewarded for it.  For some in accounting under those managers, it can be a toxic environment.  It also seemed to be very common for leaders in finance to blame problems or errors on those below them, when the real issue clearly was leadership.  This company desperately needs better leaders.

review_title: Working for Providence is working to help the poor and vulnerable
pros: Working for Providence is so much more than just working for a paycheck. Everyone on my team is incredibly committed to our mission of helping the poor and vulnerable. That mission and our core values drives what we do and how we do it.  I've seen this commitment to the mission from the highest levels of the organization to the caregiver at the bedside as well as from the people that support those caregivers so they can care for our patients.
cons: Healthcare is going through a time of enormous change and Providence is in the thick of it.  Depending on your role, the pace of change can be intense at times.

review_title: The residents are what make it worth it!
job_title: Resident Assistant in Hood River, OR
pros: The facility is in a great location. There is ease of access and it is very centralized. The residents really appreciate the care they are given.
cons: The residents pay over $5,000 a month to live at Brookside and the quality of care does not match that dollar figure. The staff is very short handed and the administration does not accept concerns from the staff.

job_title: Human Resources Customer Service Specialist in Renton, WA
pros: Providence has a pretty comprehensive benefit package, and a great mission and vision. Large company, so it really depends on your local management weather you will be happy at Providence or not.
cons: Providence is a large organization with over 100,000 employees. This means that Providence moves very SLOW, which can be very frustrating. Although Providence is large it is difficult to move positions out of an entry level position. At least it is that way at corporate HR. This is an old organization and it is very obvious.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros:
The engineering staff is committed to working together and creating successful products. 

The downtown Seattle facility is nice.
cons:
Management wants to turn this into Amazon Lite. 

Leadership is wrapped up in their own egos, does not listen to engineers, and is not trustworthy. 

The "good" Glassdoor reviews, clearly written by managers as a knee-jerk response to criticism, are indicative of why the Employee Engagement Survey results were so profoundly poor. 

The management layer is obscenely bloated- there are nearly as many managers as non-managers.

job_title: Physician, Family Practice in Chehalis, WA
pros: I love working for Providence, it is absolutely the best company I've ever worked for. In previous jobs I have never felt like the people above me really care or for that matter really listen. At Providence I feel very supported in every aspect of my professional life. I feel their mission is clear and commendable and it aligns with my intent of providing the best patient centered medical care I can. My colleagues are fantastic, my staff is amazing (friendly, responsible, helpful, engaged) and overall I'm very happy with my job here.
cons: I can't really think of many cons, most of my cons are with the healthcare system in general, which I feel Providence is at the forefront of trying to fix it

review_title: Pretty good place to work except for the constant re-orgs
pros: commitment (or at least lip-service) to the mission.  People are friendly, work-life balance is good.  Pay is ok (it is non-profit after all).
cons: really crappy medical insurance.  a bit concerned about future potential mergers and what that will do to the culture.  after each merger is a round or two of layoffs.

job_title: Cash Applications Specialist in Liberty Lake, WA
pros: The benefits are pretty decent, along with a flexible schedule at least for my position.
cons: Training not on the same page... ever, HORRIBLE leadership everyone either had no experience or was best friends with their manager so it was a conflict of interest and did not feel comfortable reporting issues or concerns, retaliation is a real thing here even though they will never admit it. They preach about their mission and values but do not actually practice them as leaders.  Didn't feel valued for hard work. Their budget is shot and they take it out on their employees.

review_title: Working at Providence has been a blessing and joy.
pros:
Teamwork
Financial Reward
Promotion opportunities
Benefits
Educational reimbursement
I have worked for many years in multiple departments and have always experienced a loyal and encouraging work environment.
cons: Some of the cons of Providence include the fact that the human resources are now outside of the hospital. We are not yet Magnet status and there is still a hierarchical structure to the organization. It also seems to be a place where jobs are offered on the basis of relationships or political clout. versus merit.

job_title: Pre Boarding Specialist in Renton, WA
pros: Very flexible hours. Kind people.
cons: From the moment I started this job there was no real type of training or manual, it was more like one day of here try this out. From then on you are just thrown into the job and at first it is not that bad but then work load quickly builds to unbearable. My coworkers are underpaid and we are understaffed, we continue to get more employees but the turn over rate is so fast people leave before we can staff. Perhaps other jobs in this company are better but as far as recruitment, I have personally never seen worse.

pros: Parking isn't bad.  Benefits are okay. Work family balance. Core Values. Some jobs have freedom- depends on the position and team. Flex time. Free Bus Pass for the year for all employees.  Wear jeans on Fridays. 403A/B standard benefits. $$ loaded onto an HSA card 700 single/ 1400 family per year.
cons: Raises -don't expect them. Every year the raises are between 0-3% of your current wage-ALWAYS. They will never pull you aside and say "you've been doing amazing here's a $1 raise" never ,ever, ever. Every year the Supervisors lie and say 'it's less then last year' Only way to move up is to find a new position. Medical insurance has a HIGH deductible (1500 self/3K family), supervisors who barely do their job. Management picking favorites(everyone sees it) Supervisors who are always gone and can't answer questions because they truly don't know the job, but it's okay because Management is okay with not knowing the job. HR is incompetent at least the OR region. People won't get fired if the don't do their job, all they have to say is they didn't get training and it's a 3 month action plan and another chance. One team operates different from another. So depending on what team you are on, you might have a flexible schedule where as another Manager requires you clock in same time everyday. No consistency between teams- NONE. Nepotism and friends hiring friends is a huge issue. If it's one person's bday, they get a party, while another person doesn't even get a card.  Stop hiring Consultants to try and find ways to save money when we all would have just been happy with $1 or 2 more an hour! Will not be surprised if this place goes union soon or at least tries too.

job_title: IS Operations Analyst II in Renton, WA
pros: Providence as a company has a great mission statement, great values, a strong economic future, and a good leadership team. The work force teams really pull together to get a lot of work done with little to no direction and are adaptable with the ever changing healthcare market. If your looking to challenge your expertise in a compassion centered work force, this is the company you want to be a part of.
cons: The system office is full of drama, and indecisive actions led by leadership not being transparent enough with employees. Management often lacks management skills and are not reviewed by peers. Past experience has shifted the culture of system office workers to hold back opinions and ideas due to management's unwilling to learn from lower level employees.

pros: Providence is a great place to work for. Even as an entry level employee, they generally take good care of you. Plus, they're widespread and in every field in healthcare.
cons:
Bureaucratic BS. I guess this applies to every company, but they seem to move through extra thick molasses sometimes. Leadership shuffles in my department constantly, with some truly horrific managers being placed in charge and taking forever to be removed.

Oh, and completely redoing their dietary department multiple times within the space of a few years. Mass chaos...

review_title: Overworking nurses and adding more and more to do for daily assignments.
pros: Good management, good co-workers, self-scheduling, flexible weekends
cons: High patient acuity, overload on nurses, stressful, mean doctors, demanding workload

pros: Providence is a large nonprofit organization. Pay and the benefit is just average depending on your level of your career. HSA incentives is wonderful for to use for copays.
cons: Management is lucking leadership skills. Some department have managers that have no inputs what’s going on the ground level. Even if you ask them for help, they just excuse themselves “ I have meeting to go”. No room for constructive feedback. Moral is so low. Toxic work environment and hostile. Employees harasses and insults each other. High turnout.

pros:
- Nonprofit company that gives back to the community
- Work aligns with their mission
- Feel like you are making a difference and able to help Patients
- Good work environment
- HSA/HRA insurance provides health incentives with front loading $ to pay your medical bills each year
- Rarely take work home with you
cons:
- Minimal pay increase with yearly reviews
- Lack of recognition for going above and beyond
- No outlined career path or growth opportunities
- Leadership doesn't listen to new ideas of how to improve the workplace or work/life balance
- Benefits are decent, but plans are still with a high deductible
- No options to work remotely

pros: Great benefits, including medical, dental, life insurance, paid time off, "personal enrichment days" given in addition to sick days and paid time off, numerous discounts, even a personal assistant service if needed. Amazing and intelligent people, and a fast-paced work environment. Time and a half pay if you work more than 8 hours in a day and 40 hours in a week for this position.
cons: Odd hours, never enough parking if you work swing shift at the hospital. Patients can sometimes be difficult, as this position requires you to request insurance and co-pays in a time when they are often in pain or receiving bad news.

pros: I liked working at Covenant.  I worked there 20 years.  My last position was in the cashiering department in the Business Office.  After we took on 5 St. Joseph of Orange hospitals plus all the ones we were already posting for, it was a bit overwhelming, and when I was offered the retirement package after training 5 new employees to take my place I took the package.
cons: Before I decided to take the package they would not hire help.  I guess it took five people to take my place.

job_title: Master Black Belt in Seattle, WA
pros: Highly Mission driven gives everyone a purpose to come to work. A job where you can truly make an impact on your community. Lately, a lot of focus on people development and succession planning and partnering with other non profits locally and internationally to take the mission forward
cons: Less diverse for my taste but it goes with healthcare as an industry. The salary is very competitive for the industry but being a non profit bonus is not as big in comparison to what you would get in a tech company here in Seattle.

pros: I worked in Recruiting, and we had flexibility to work remote, which was great.  The overall environment was collaborative and collegial, so group projects were truly a team effort.
cons: HR at Providence is lead by Caucasian leaders at all levels.  In Recruiting, if you were not a Caucasian Female, similar to other leaders, there was a glass ceiling over your head.  It was well known that people of color do not fare well at Providence.  I was even interviewed by HR Legal around what I witnessed in Recruiting around discriminatory practices, even legal knows there are issues, yet nothing is done about it.  I left Providence because no matter how much my work was praised, I was never worthy of being promoted.  Ironically, people below me, and of course Caucasian, were always given more opportunity.

review_title: A bad engineering organization, a nice place to do nothing and get paid.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer Digital Innovation Group in Seattle, WA
pros: People are nice generally and you can show up at 930, leave at 430 or 5 and no one seems to care.   If you just want a job that you show up to, do whatever you're told to regardless of if its a good decision, get paid and go home then this is a great place to work.
cons:
WFH was revoked without notice or cause for entire team.

Management is focused around pretty graphs in jira over delivering quality software.   

Employee standards are arbitrary and enforced wildly differently depending on the manager.

Claim to be agile, but are really just waterfall without the ability to commit to long term plans.  

Extremely dysfunctional inter team communication.  

RCA meetings are aggressive and used as tools for punishing employees rather than to resolve actual meaningful issues.

Software is barely used by customers, managers or leadership.   Its not unusual to have the product owner of a product lecture at length about features which are no longer in existence, because they haven't run the software in two months.

Many internal "norms" which are codified in a norms sheet.  These are used to encourage people to "have backbone" or "have fun" or "crave constructive conflict".   In reality these are used as a means to bludgeon employees via reviews - either by not following them, following them too much, or frequently one followed immediately by the other.

The biggest one:  this is not a startup.   Its the software arm of a behemoth healthcare organization which does not understand engineering in any way.  Incentives from top to bottom are focused on appeasing the bureaucracy rather than solving problems.  They will obscure this fact by talking about agile, drive to go further, customer obsession etc... And I think there's a genuine desire for that to be true.   It is not.

review_title: Good culture, great place to start out with opportunity to advance
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Orange, CA
pros: The culture at this hospital was excellent. I met some of the most hardworking patient centered people and learned a great deal from co-workers. Great learning environment. This was a great starting job for me in healthcare and will help me in the future.
cons: The ever changing landscape of healthcare poses challenges for all hospitals requiring administration to make different changes that may or may not seem to be in the best interest of patients and staff but rather the bottom line. Additionally, my values conflict with those of this private health care system and while it did not come up in my personal day to day work, I would like to avoid this in the future. Pay was lower compared to other nearby positions.

review_title: Great company and industry but red tape abound
pros:
- balance of work and life outside
- decent pay if you get in at good level
- good people
cons:
- always behind the curve on technology
- office environment work is not very exciting here
- constantly being smothered with religious material, emails, and other catholic centric stuff
- preaching diversity but really only recognizing catholosism 
- all upper management are fossils. No new young talent leading this company
- more red tape and forms, committees etc. every year making things take a very long time to do
- censored environment, you always have to watch what you say.

review_title: watching a real mess unfold with "integration" and mergers
pros: charitable mission of the organization has always been good thing, dedication to the poor and less privileged, big complex organization
cons: this merger between two big hospital organizations has been a real mess.  Layoffs and scrambling and really not well thought out at many levels.  We have watched the "strategy" and "integration" brass pad their salaries and benefits in this deal and cut convenient high salaries for themselves when the rest of the organization seems to be suffering throughout all of the region.  Poor communication and lots of folks worried about their jobs but visible smugness at the top of the organization chart.

review_title: The most Mission/Values oriented place I
pros: If what you want to do is make a difference in the world, being able to help the poor and vulnerable is about as meaningful an organizational focus as you can have.  In addition, Providence is very stable financially in a difficult industry, and has recently started pursuing investments and innovation in healthcare at a pace that few other organizations can match.
cons: The corporate support functions like HR and IT are way behind the high standards met by clinical and other operational areas.  As Providence continues to grow, coordination across silos is becoming more challenging.  Although there is a strong focus internally on ensuring that Providence maintains those parts of its culture that are most important, there is a sense that there is some "drift".

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: As a young and obviously LGBTQ person coming in to this Catholic hospital I was initially concerned that I would have problems with comfort and acceptance. People have been nothing but kind and friendly since the moment I walked in. The culture is one of family and encouraging everyone to do their best, even encouraging employees to pursue jobs in other departments.
cons: The only con I can think of right now is that there isn't enough parking for all employees, but that's hardly a deal breaker.

review_title: Nice area,  coworkers work well together
job_title: Registered Nurse in West Covina, CA
pros: Free, convenient parking,lovely area with small town feel, took into account my schedule preferences, had enough supplies, acuity of pts fairly low (no open heart/cath lab, trauma level), pt's were overall sweet - don't act entitled, co-workers were courteous, usually helpful, seem like just good people.
cons: MEDITECH!  Physicians seem patriarchal, rude, not my favorite, floated every shift, sometimes twice a shift (floated within 2 hours of beginning shift).   A large majority of my sweet patients did not speak the same language as I, which is a bit of a challenge, but they were patient with me.  Really helps if you are bilingual here (would like to learn, but takes time).

job_title: Physician Business Services/PBS in Portland, OR
pros: The staff at Providence Health & Services were by far some of the best people I've had the opportunity to with.  The overall atmosphere was very positive, staff were very helpfull and happy to be there. PH&S also was transparent with their business plans and overall health of the company by having regular meetings every 3 months - I found that very refreshing.
cons: Management changes too often. Favoritism was clearly showed to friends of Management, as those were the employee's that were promoted rather than staff that was most qualified, time and again. Finding parking was difficult.

job_title: Physician, Family Practice in Torrance, CA
pros: Good pay doing hybrid system. Good flexibility over hours, scheduling, and control over my practice.
cons: Significantly less help than Kaiser where you have lots of support and ancillary staff to off load non-physician work. I get lots of messages such as "I need help paying for this bill", "will my insurance cover this?",  "can you please schedule my ultrasound appointment", "I don't know how to contact the refill line, I want you to call the pharmacy and figure it out" and so forth. There is no filter and this all goes straight to me. 80-90% of my paperwork is things like this.

review_title: Say one thing - do another style leadership team
job_title: Operations Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Inspiring mission and the history of the organization is something to be proud of and celebrate.
cons:
They run it like a Tenant hospital. The only thing they truly care about is money, yet the leadership speaks with platitudes. They speak of moral high ground, but they execute on the moral low ground. Nurses are unhappy. Doctors are unhappy. Staff tune out leadership due to the duplicitous nature of the leadership team in Renton.

Under investing in their core services (hospitals). 

The only leadership with real authority is in Renton. Everyone else lacks any ability to do anything of substance for their community and the employees.

Leadership relies too heavily on the “history” instead of creating something relevant and forward for our community.

pros: Providence is an organization that truly exemplifies our mission and lives by our core values.  There is such a level of respect and collaboration that I have not seen in other organizations. The leadership team is dynamic, creative and compassionate. Providence is on the cutting edge of healthcare innovation.  It is remarkable to work for such an amazing organization. I appreciate the flexibility offered.
cons: I have read some of the reviews on Providence.  I have not had the poor experience that some have described.  We have a term called "Providence nice"  and I have only ever seen that type of behavior from leadership and my peers.  Compensation is a bit less than other organizations, but the work life balance far exceeds.

pros: The only good reason to work here is they at least can pay you on time.
cons: Everyone has seniority.  There are too many masters and not enough slaves.  Management has offered others working at competing hospital with less experience nearly 40% more to come work here, and turnover in this department is high because the educated ones will not stay since the ones less educated have favored the right people to make all the decisions.  Pay rates are a laughable and the drama is endless.

pros: I enjoy working for Providence and will continue as long as they will have me.  I enjoy the work/life balance and they are really in tune with taking care of YOU.  I enjoy coming to work each day and seeing positive people.  There are always resources for me if I get behind in my work, or if I ask for help with the work load.  AWESOME benefits and pay.
cons: Sometimes you have many managers asking things from you, but I don't think they have communicated.  Sometimes there are too many "hands in the pot" and it's hard to tell who really needs what.

review_title: Cohesive Staff Level; Managers and Directors Display "Power."
pros: The staff level of employees make sincere efforts to support the mission and each other.  Benefits and wages are comparable to other local institutions, although not at the top of the scale.
cons: The visions and desires of the upper level executives are not reflected in the behaviors and actions of the department managers who seem to be more interested in maintaining and displaying their "power" over the staff.  There is little opportunity for advancement or movement into different fields with jobs being filled with friends and family.

job_title: Laboratory Clerk in Mission Hills, CA
pros: I like what i do in my department in the laboratory. I process specimens and do customer service rep both at the same time. I like working with people mostly the CLS and Phlebotomist. But work and greet people all the time.
cons: The only down fall i can think of right now is mainly what I've been fighting for this past 8 to 9 years.  Becoming a full-time employee at my work. I am currently part-time with full benefits. But not enough pay for the things they want me to do. I work more then 48hrs, mostly almost 75 to 80 hrs with 2wks. My availability varies. If they need me I'm available morning, day and night.

pros:
1. Feeling you might be making a difference for those in your community. 
2. Staff who are collaborative and energized by the Mission and Vision of the Sisters of Providence.
cons:
1. Underpaid employees often overqualified for positions. 
2. Cultural disconnection between Mission and Values of Providence and ACTUAL working environment. 
3. Poor Structural Hierarchy-limited advancement opportunities.
4. Lack of strong, decisive, focused, global-minded leadership.

pros: Great Benefits, some great people and mission. Easy commute, free parking and nice cafeteria with decent  food prices. Safe working environment.
cons:
Unqualified managers who not only have never been mgrs before but also do not understand what they are doing. Very biased HR dept. that doesn't put employee's concerns first instead ends up siding with management.
Lots of open positions but they don't promote from within. Many overworked employees, no one cares how many hrs you have to put in to get the job done.

pros: The ability to focus upon the stated mission of the organization in all work capacities, while that was still a viable pursuit.
cons: Steadily deteriorating organizational focus upon mission tenets due to industry pressures to expand too quickly, which resulted in executive leadership placement of individuals unqualified for core aspects of their roles, who were unprepared to recruit input from the experts at operational levels so as to realize optimal operating and patient care outcomes and proper leveraging of experienced IT personnel to successfully and efficiently integrate disparate technical infrastructure. Decreasing focus upon mission and vocational / developmental welfare of staff across disciplines.

review_title: Great job, if you are not looking for a promotion!
pros: The best reason to work for Covenant is the ability to work in a fexible environment.  My department is very small so I have a lot of freedom to work at my own pace, give my own creative input, and in some ways be my own boss.  With Covenant's paid time off we receive about 7 hours per pay period that we can take at any time with approval of course.
cons: The type of work I was hired to do did not require a degree so the payscale is not contingent with my experience.  Since my department is so small there is not an opportunity for a promotion, otherwise this would be the perfect job!

pros: room for growth, a large company so many opportunities, the people really care about eachother, the quality of work is important to leadership, no layoffs have been done during the tough economy.
cons: leadership has staff working on too many large initiatives at once with no clear direction.  It can be difficult to move up the ladder but not impossible.

review_title: Leadership and morale have spiraled downward for several years. Now with the 'Opulent NEW TOWER', morale at bottom
pros: If you can believe the 'Mission' of the Sisters of Providence, it helps get you through and bring job satisfaction.
cons: But the reality is... all of that is just crap. They only care about money and numbers, period. Do not care for their staff one bit. It is now glaringly evident to anyone NOT in Management. Management is like a Cult or evil Sect. Unbelievable.

pros: It's great to know what you are doing is a part of the Providence Mission.  Benefits are fair.
cons: Pay is below market (even if you include Renton in the Tacoma Pool).  Top down info sharing is almost non existent.  For a Non-Profit, the culture is becoming very corporate, and not in a good way.  Favoritism, politics, backstabbing all get in the way of what once was an amazing place to work.  Takes forever to get anything done and projects are almost always way behind schedule.  Very frustrating place to work.

pros: Great staff, philosophy of care, common vision shared from top down, overall respect for volunteers and one another
cons: Excessive negative talk about others  among some teams/staff, assumptions the norm rather than curiosity/asking questions, excessive training time and lack of trust for new  employees.  A very difficult place to be accepted in some teams, though relatively easy to form friendly, respectful relationships in organization as a whole

pros: Usually have all the equipment needed to do your job, lots of resources to make things easier
cons: Very money driven, supplies will often be replaced with cheaper ineffective versions of the product, management is not interested in hearing anything you have to say unless it is positive or saves them money, they will completely tune you out if you have anything less than positive to say or suggest. Does not care about individual staff, everyone is extremely replaceable and they just refer everyone back to policy without regard for individual circumstances or situations - I have seen so many amazing nurses get burned because Providence is a large company that is unwilling to change or compromise to accommodate illness or injury to employees or their family members

review_title: 10 year employee - time to move on
pros: I get a paycheck every two weeks
cons: Senior management LIES!!!  That's all they do.  We never have clear direction, nobody knows anything.  ALL the good competent and reliable people have left.  Good people are leaving in droves.  Too much work with no unity.  The left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing.  All attempts to have regionalization  and do what they do at the system office is a failure

review_title: If patient safety, annual salary, and benefits are of no importance to you, work here!
job_title: Acute Care Staff Registered Nurse in Everett, WA
pros: Serves underprivileged patient populations and local communities. Charitable towards patients that dont have ability to pay.  Nursing staff continues to show caring compassion towards patients regardless off the way they are treated by administrators.
cons: Non-competitive salary compared to other local hospitals,  poor benefits package,  patient to medical staffing ratios are borderline dangerous leading to rapid burnout, total disconnect between administrative staff and medical staff, weak union representation for CNA, techs, and nursing staff.

review_title: St. Joseph used to be an excellent place to work, due to the lack of staff it is now horrific.
pros: Pharmacy staff is excellent, as well as PT, OT, speech and RT.  The house administrators are the best of the best.
cons:
Short staffed
Upper management not supportive
No matching on the 403b
Equipment is faulty and old
People need to be held accountable to do their job 
Housekeeping does not clean to standards

review_title: Variable-they had difficulty keeping the managers, so it depended on which manager was running the unit.
pros: It is a big organization which can give many opportunities and places to transfer to.
cons:
Providence does a great job of "Ease my way" for their patients but the same isn't true for its employees.
Managers often have to much power and don't listen to the staff.
They have had multiple grievances brought against management by ONA that ONA has won or Providence has 'settled'.

pros: The people are truly great both technically as well as interpersonally which gives the work environment a bit of that family feel.
cons: Significant growth has exposed opportunities to improve processes and communication which have sometimes proven difficult to address due to the corporations large size and matrixed  structure.

pros: Worked in the Mission Heritage division and it was the worst working experience I have had in 40 years. The pay is terrible, the place is filled with backstabbing,menopausal women including the CEO, and overall the medical care is marginal. The people who work here are from another planet (or Mexico) and no one speaks English.
