cons: Everything...no vacation days, just "PTO" - you will use most of it to take holidays off with none leftover for your freetime. The pay is barely a living wage in Orange County. My clinic had dead rats in the walls and ceiling - patients always asked what "the smell was" in the office. Unsanitary practices and scary attitudes - I can't believe my own doctor worrks for this horriblke place. STAY AWAY!!! Providence is taking over Hoag, St Joseph and St Jude next year...wish them luck.

review_title: If your're an "apple polisher", this is the place for you !
pros:
Great co-workers, everyone in my business unit was a team player, only a couple of 
 exceptions. The business process is very efficient.
cons: Management is a joke. They change the rules as it suits them, favoritism is shown in salaries and workload, nepotism abounds, most of the managers who came and went during my years at Providence spent the better portion of the day gossiping . They are comfortable misrepresenting the truth. Admin. staff witnesses their unprofessional behavior each and every day but are afraid to speak up.

review_title: Values based company turned upside down by industry and company change.
job_title: Human Resources Leader in Renton, WA
pros: Strong mission and values. Strategically positioned (3rd largest non profit healthcare company in United States) for growth in the future. Interesting opportunities.
cons: For corporate employees - extremely challenging to get things done given rate of change. Lack of clarity on roles and responsibilities. Focus on "espousing" rather than "living" vision. Has gone about the change process in an unstructured way creating confusion, lack of accountability, and frustration among caregivers (Providence name for employees). Extremely political with too many layers.

pros: I love working at Providence because of our promise to know, care for, and ease the way of everyone we serve.  I enjoy knowing every day that the work I do helps our communities up and down the West Coast.  And I love the people I work with - we are all here to do good.
cons: We pride ourselves on our humility.   This is not the place for arrogant or egotistical people.  You need to be very willing to work in a collaborative environment.

pros: Providence has A+ mission statement
cons: The pay is not good, fair, or equitable. The salary review process is a joke as they look for ways to not give you a pay adjustment. They pay significantly lower than the area standard.

review_title: On my way out.. .but the pay is great for the area.
pros:
Good pay due to remoteness and nobody wants to live here.
Beautiful surroundings (if you can handle the homelessness).
Management is nice to your face.
cons: Mgmt asks for advice and guidance from employees, and even will give positive feedback that advice given is worthy of implementation... yet never is.  If they are just flapping gums because it's what the board of directors expects, it's not a place I intend to stay.  10 years of giving advice and being told it's good/usable/perfect... I can take a hint.

review_title: Good place to work, typical hospital hierarchy and bureaucracy.
pros: The hospital is very modern and efficient. There are many excellent nurses and charge nurses. Teamwork is great with the other CNAs and the level of independence to perform ones job is nice too. Opportunity to change departments or train for ward clerk is available.
cons:
As a CNA, you should be accustomed to the bottom of the totem pole. Patient ratios are always on the high side, many RNs assume you are dumb, and prepare to be floated around without a say. 
Staffing will call you on every one of your days off, and watch out because sometimes they will change your schedule without notice.

pros:
* Wonderful support in both time and energy from supervisors
* Dedicated people passionate about what they do
* Organized company, well-run meetings
* Cares about doing the right thing
* Responsive in getting employees sit-stand desks or equipment they need
cons:
* Can be a little 'churchy' with reflections that can at times seem like little sermons at the beginning of most meetings
* Such a large company that some people and groups can get "silo-ed" and it can feel hard to get some things accomplished
* New positions seem to take a long time to inch through HR before being posted

job_title: Senior Executive Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great mission, strong values, continual learning is encouraged, salary is higher than industry, benefits are good, commute subsidy, snacks and coffee. WFH
cons: does not cover maternity or paternity leave, you have to take a  leave of absence.

job_title: Cash Applications Specialist in Liberty Lake, WA
pros: Employment. Employees bond over not enjoying their work and wishing management would listen and change how they manage things.
cons: Poor pay. For a production focused job there is no incentive to achieve more than the minimum. Management lead with a stick versus a carrot. During employee meeting you are reminded that if you do not meet the new production numbers that there is someone out there that can do your job better and you are replaceable. Providence has purchased software that will be able to automate most of the positions in the Business Office.

pros: Sacred Heart is one of the most stable employers in the region. There were some layoffs a few years ago, but things have really turned around and they are hiring for more new positions again. They offer good pay and solid benefits, and being such a large workplace, there is plenty of opportunity for development and advancement.
cons: There seems to be a tolerance for mediocre and low performance, from front-line staff to middle and upper management as well. This includes physicians as well. There is a lot of pressure to be fast, with not as much effort towards quality. Mistakes and errors are covered up and forgotten, instead of dealing with them openly and transparently.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant Level II in Eugene, OR
pros: Good benefits, average pay, good company morals, expanding hospital branch.  Committed to employees, good mission statement and morals.  Difficult to achieve upward mobility on internal transfers.
cons: Pay is competitive.  Difficult to achieve a promotion.  Benefits are good if you work full time.  If you are per diem you are basically on your own.  Overall management of company finances and priorities has seemed questionable.

pros:
Interaction with patients in their home setting
Close to home
Great coworkers 
I can't think of anything else. I can't come up with 20 pro words
cons: This company has been worsening in regards to clinician expectations, not listening to our concerns, patient care severely affected, and overall poor morale. We, as clinicians, are treated as kids who don't know how to do our job, including being monitored and treated as a robot vs. a professional who is providing great care for years with this company.

pros: I have found this company to be very flexible and worthwhile. Easy to earn PTO, very easy with scheduling and requests. Also very easy to advance to different areas. Pay starts off a little low but raises are frequent.
cons: Management can be lacking at times, oversight is not as high as it should be. On-call is feast or famine for hours.

review_title: Good pay, good people, moving way too fast causes burnout.
pros: Competitive pay. Work from home 2 days a week. Office is 5 minutes from home. Good people. Did I say you get to work from home? Only epic analysts though.
cons: Bad benefits, no employee perks, epic analysts being forced to do go lives constantly with no breaks. I’ve been there for 5 years, and am searching for a job because all providence does is expand, buy places out and do go lives. It never ends.  If you like traveling, being pushed to your limits and getting burned out get a job there you’ll love it.

job_title: Office Services Clerk in Beaverton, OR
pros: Providence is a great company if you're a customer. They take care of their customers well, and will have company BBQ's once in a blue moon to give people time to socialize.
cons: Leadership/Management is disappointing. They all say that they are open to input, but then they bury their heads in the sand, and ignore problems that can lead to incredible failure. No true room for advancement without switching departments. Pay is incredibly low and not market rate.

pros: Up-to-date technology, Beautiful facilities, Good staff, Many opportunities to continue education, Ongoing training, fair practices, evidence based practices, good place to work. Many doctors are very kind.
cons: The only con I can think of is the staffing ratios at times with extremely busy patients. Some doctors at times can be rude and no one seems to do anything about it. Lunch breaks should be a time of rest but you get in trouble if you lay your head down or choose to take a small nap.

pros: OUR department is very much a team. I have not worked anywhere else where the interdepartment communication and collaboration is as good as here. Good benefits and a high sense of self satisfaction with the work we do. Median overall pay but is expected from a mission serving no profit hospital system like this.
cons: Prov St. Joseph is a big company now, which means things can move slowly up through the bureaucratic process of middle management.

review_title: Safe" employment, but at the cost of your professional growth
pros:
-Job security (although layoffs and firings becoming more common)

-Rank-and-file staffers generally friendly and competent (although morale is low and continues to sink)

-Admirable Mission on paper (if only today's corporate management cared to live up to it)

-Office spaces in newer Halsey facilities in Portland are pleasant and centrally located by public tranportation

-Benefits package is decent and includes TriMet annual passes, health coverage, 401k and retirement savings account for full-timers (although leadership continues to trim benefits each year)
cons:
Years ago, Providence was an A+ employer ... today, you would not recognize that employer:

-Salary/bonus compensation is pathetically low and out of touch with today's job market. Don't expect a "real" annual raise (max 2%), no matter how strong your performance review; and expect a token $25 Safeway gift certificate (no cash value) for your annual bonus around Christmas 

-Executive managment is struggling to find its way in this new era of healthcare: lack of vision, lack of focus, mired in bureaucatic and outdated thinking

-Nepotisism: If you're a relative of a top executive, esteemed physician or wealthy Foundations' donor, regardless of your skills, you'll advance rapidly ... otherwise, good luck

-Career growth is snail's pace. A big part of the problem is Providence's tendancy to look outside for management hires rather than look for or grow loyal, internal talent (the longer you're  there, the fewer your chances of being promoted)

-Diversity: For a Mission-driven company that seeks to care for the poor and vulnerable, tragically few people of color and other diverse backgrounds given the size of the organization. To add insult, the company does not recognize MLK Day as a paid holiday. Over the years, the company has steadily marginalized its own diversity department to maintain the homogenous status quo. 

-Work/life balance: used to be a "pro," but now individual employees are expected to produce the work formerly done by three employees. Rather than management saying "no" to senseless work requests, the polite culture is to never turn down a request...even if it comes in last minute and requires you to work past midnight

-Training and tools: Providence's internal training tools are outdated and inadequate and will ensure that you fall behind in your craft/skills. Meaningful training (or training that requires any expense and/or travel) is for Director-level and above ranks only (another example of top-down management culture)

- Top-down management: Providence is the epitomy of this outdated organizational culture. Bosses sit in big corner offices while the minions are crammed into cubes. Get used to asking permission, and you will learn to do things "the Providence way," whether it's right, wrong or terribly outdated

job_title: Department: Marketing & Communications in Portland, OR
pros: They mean well, and try hard to be 'nice' People are great. Pay and benefits are on par.
cons:
No vision, no leadership. No long term strategy, or direction for the department. 
Leadership has demonstrated no background or ability to run dept effectively, beyond crisis management. Being indispensable in the moment, is fine. But how about demonstrating some long term leadership and strategy?

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in Anchorage, AK
pros: I loved the mission of caring for all people regardless of status or financial ability to pay in full.  The team atmosphere of working in a dynamic cutting edge health care facility is not like any other workplace I have been involved in.  Providence paid a good hourly wage with excellent benefits during my time there.  Once you work at PAMC there were opportunities to explore different career paths as employees often got first chance at other job openings.  I truly enjoyed my coworkers a great deal.
cons: I have been gone several years and honestly cannot think of any right off hand.  I would be very interested in working at PAMC again.

job_title: Patient Services Representative in Walla Walla, WA
pros: You can seek medical attention from all the stress that is caused by this employer. You never knew what your coworkers were up to.  There was so much hate at this work place.  People fight, literally fight for this position. So wound recovery is easy in a medical establishment.
cons: Backstabbers work at Providence. Watch your back as no one is your friend in this work place.  When you sit in on corporate meetings, you discover that they are upset that there are less visits to the ER as those visits make them money. Shouldn't we celebrate that people are taking better care of themselves? Not at Providence. It's all about the $$$

review_title: An exciting, inspiring place to be!
pros:
Health care is changing dramatically everyday- new health care policies sociologically, new advances in medical processes & procedures, cutting-edge medicines & treatments to implement, new organizational systems and tools to implement, and new and unique challenges to respond to from the communities that we serve. Providence is re-inventing itself in order to best integrate and reflect those exciting new changes in dynamic ways within the organization, and doing it all with a strong mission to 'ease the way' of those who come to us for compassionate care.  

As a mission-focused, non-profit, the purpose we serve and the values that unite us are referenced daily.  The 'heart' of the organization is something that is externally acknowledged and cared for consciously.

The people that I interact with daily act with the patient in mind every day- whether they are in a hospital or clinical setting or an administrative role (e.g., Finance, IT, HR, etc.)  I get to work with focused, compassionate, smart, and committed people every day.

I honestly feel 'on the edge' in a good way as an employee at Providence- on the edge of operationalizing visionary sociological & medical changes, on the edge with break-through thinking that can make a difference within the Providence organization, and on the edge of crafting solutions that positively affect the world and the people that I live with every day.
cons:
The PROS captured the vision and aspirational energy of Providence, translating that into day-to-day operations is a BIG challenge, and sometimes feels like it can't happen fast enough and  can be very frustrating.  Change is like that.

There is recognition from all that it is a time of much change.  We need to reinvent ourselves to be a more capably deliver on our health care service promises.  AND as those changes are being defined and implemented, there is work to do...lots of work.  Therein, lies the rub.

The CON I described above is not an uncommon situation- I've worked in a good variety of organizations and industries.  What is different here is the size of the changes that are needed- health care is revolutionizing, not simply evolving.  Providence needs to revolutionize too (i.e., upgrade our organizational technologies, continue to add skilled talent to the workforce, develop the skills of existing caregivers/ employees, ensure that our desire and processes for innovation become 'the norm,' etc...).    Frankly, there are times when 'the old ways' get in our way of integrating 'the new ways.'  But then I reflect back on the phenomenal opportunity of our vision and mission and am refueled, but it would be excellent and more efficient if some of the above revolutionary changes could happen even faster!

pros: Amazing work culture with history deep in foundationa inspire you to want to work here.   However the last 18 month's in my over 5 year tenure have been the most difficult and challenging from yoyo management leading change with inexperience and a insider club feel for any chance at opportunity.
cons: Poor middle management, lack of development or career advancement, emphasis on job promotion based on politics and inside connection instead of seniority, dedication, skill or teamwork. Bad stewardship and decisons leading to budgets not met and deep cuts. More work for less pay.

review_title: Great place to work if you work for the right leaders
pros:
-Mission Driven
-Mostly great staff
-Get the opportunity to help people when you work in a direct patient care environment
cons:
-Non-direct patient care teams can easily lose sight of mission
- In some departments the only way to get ahead, get vacation approved, or get a good review is by sucking up to bad supervisors or by being friends with or related to a Manager or Director
-Some departments have too many cliques

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Spokane, WA
pros: They do a great job of fulfilling "the mission". They have good benefits etc.
cons: after being here for 8.5 years my pay topped out at at 20.30 per hour. There is a PCC (receptionist) that makes 1 dollar less than me. I have 20 years experience. It is a good place for new MA's to work but not good if you are the "boots on the ground" long term. Because of this I have to resign and work somewhere else where I will be compensated for the work I do and be compensated for having an education beyond what a receptionist does.

pros: The organization has excellent mission, vision and values, and works hard to communicate and engage employees to relate to and understand how their work contributes to the mission.
cons: Like any company there are politics at play. Since I left there has been a CEO change, and the IT department has a new CIO. I don't know how that has changed things, but there was a need for centralization and standardization, and there were too many managers in place at that time fro the size the organization was heading to be (smaller)

review_title: PH&S Digital Innovation Group - attracting top talent!
job_title: Technical Product Director in Seattle, WA
pros: Pushing the envelope to create an awesome healthcare experience for our patients.  Leadership is very business oriented and with good technical depth  –  great place for innovative technical people to work.
cons: Challenges are related to operational and security complexity due to working in healthcare. And also to the fact that Providence is a huge organization of 75,000 employees.

review_title: Ministry Organizational Mission is anything but Ministerial
job_title: Business Performance Advisor in Renton, WA
pros: Quality of care. High volume facilities. Luxurious spending when it comes to patients and delivery of care, but meager towards employees. Which is admirable.
cons:
Vindictive actions toward employees who are qualified and competent from those that are "deadwood" and barely have the skills or qualifications to be in the positions they are. 
Who you know will get you ahead, knowing your job, does not.
Backstabbing is the worst, and furthermore, tolerated in the workplace.
Bullying seems to rule the roost.
Least professional company I've ever set foot in. 
DO NOT uphold ethics and standards.

pros: The ED has great staff who care about safety and patient care.  A vibrant and fun place to work, I kept in touch with many coworkers after leaving. Providence has a mission statement and corporate ethics which care for those in need. Floors are well staffed. For diverse employees and patients they go the extra mile to be respectful of other religions (they are a Catholic institution) and ethnic backgrounds. The cafeteria has hours after midnight for night crew. FREE public transportation on Portland buses & the MAX.
cons: Incremental raises in pay sometimes feel mediocre, but higher level employees getting a 4-10% increase in wage would be much more impacting than someone making $20 per hour.

pros: There are many people who work at Providence who embody the Core Values. They care about their patients and their teammates and providing excellent care to our patients. The medical/dental/STD/LTD benefits are excellent and substantially subsidized or free. There is a sense of pride about the organization's heritage, and the legacy of the Sisters of Providence.
cons:
Where to begin? It's doubtful that I will stay based on limited promotional opportunities and the current HR leadership. Employee engagement is suffering. You can do all the employee surveys you want, but if you don't walk the talk and provide effective leadership, opportunities for advancement, and a positive work environment, you can't blame people for leaving. 

The organization has horrible systems integration, and getting a new hire up and running on basic items such as computer equipment, passwords, systems access and training is an exercise in frustration. While I can appreciate that huge organizations have complex needs, other huge organizations seem to manage to put together systems and infrastructure that actually work well. Now that Providence has merged with St. Joseph, I can only imagine that it will get worse. We do not provide a friendly, welcoming experience for our new caregivers. 

Leadership training is non-existent. Purportedly, DDI is coming back to Providence. Again. I hope that opportunities for leadership development will extend down to the mid-level manager ranks because they get nothing at the moment. 

Large organizations have a hard time being nimble, and Providence is not encouraging of new ideas, out of the box thinking, creativity nor best practices. This is particularly true of the HR organization, which is mired in 1950's style HR practices and thinking. It's non-strategic and stodgy. 

Salaries are low. Paid time off benefits are sub-par.

This is an organization at a crossroads. Healthcare is a rapidly changing environment, and I understand that we need to be competitive. But what has made Providence great in the past is in peril. Is it too much to ask to lose the Swedish executive team that now runs the place? Probably. Cultures and companies change, not always for the better. My hope is that we won't lose sight of what made Providence an excellent organization for many years. I want to be proud of where I work, proud that I'm supporting policies that support our values and proud of our leadership team. I don't feel that way any more, and I'm not alone in this perspective.

pros: Good work life balance and competitive pay. Everyone is usually respectful of others. A company mission that you can be proud of...
cons: Senior leadership is constantly making reckless decisions to acquire/merge/affiliate/etc. that negatively impacts the good people making the entire system run. Before things can be stabilized, leadership continues to throw monkey wrenches with more and more mergers and acquisitions. Providence's identity is lost and will continue to be muddled with the St. Joseph merger. Where are the Sisters?

review_title: I love to work for SJH, because I learn and make new friends daily.
pros: The pay is better than most employers, the constant turn over makes work life exciting.  LOVE, and Compassion, is offerd by many.  Just being in the church like work place makes you feel watched over by god.
cons: The Complaints from employees are not followed through with completely, this makes you want to move outside the box.  There should be a better way to handle things.

review_title: Providence is a good company with good intentions that is also a good employer
pros: Providence has a great mission and really tries to accomplish it. The senior leadership are very good at communicating down the plans they have for Providence. The benefit package is pretty good and the people are overall very nice.
cons: Providence is the largest private employer in Oregon. With size comes some bureaucracy. Things are sometimes slow to change within. However, I think for a large company Providence is faster than average.

review_title: The Queen used to be a good place to work, but is not any longer.
pros:
Salary and benefits are adequate.
Employees are still a good group to work with.
cons:
"Under New Management", which is accelerating the rate of decline over the previous management.
Management is treating employees as if they are replaceable parts, not people. Staffing is being cut in all areas and morale is plummeting, and all management can think about is "competing with Kaiser", while raising prices and driving away customers (patients and physicians).

review_title: What an amazing place to work...
pros: I had come from the high tech industry and was used to bottom line and whatever makes the most money - this is a place that focuses on making a better experience for the patient and truly helping people to heal and live healthier lives.  It's about team work, working in a positive environment and helping your peers with their work as well.
cons: It's a bit fragmented with so many locations across so many states, but it's something people acknowledge and work on consistently

review_title: Former system employee out of Renton, WA
pros: There are some great people out in the facilities trying to do the best they can in the front lines
cons: Very top heavy, management totally out of touch with what is going on at the patient care level. Put all of those Master Black Belts to work streamlining processes or fixing processes that are completely broken. Benefits were severely lacking.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Portland, OR
pros: Has strong guiding principles for their core values. much lip service is given to this. majority of employees connect with and try to exemplify this mission.
cons: company offers few, if any perks. management expects employees to give 150% of their energy to fulfill this mission, but the demands on employee workload is often so heavy that it takes a hard toll.

pros: The allure of flexible schedule, autonomy and promise of kind culture work environment.
cons:
Once immersed into the culture of the clinic,  it was apparent I was deceived about the state of culture and scheduling promises. Management used subversive tactics to control and not lead the team.  The toxic work environment combined with poor communicating led to subpar employee satisfaction.  

When confronted about high employee turn over, cultural and personal bullying, management denied or would not respond.  It was taken one step further with a positive work performance review and then later denial of employee reimbursement for education, based on social differences. This had a  flavor of retaliation based on difference of opinion. 

There is a sacred cow mindset within a certain few individuals which is supported from management, combined with borderline nepotism and punative management style.

Highly recommend staying away from this entity.

job_title: Home Health RN in Orange, CA
pros: Some very caring, competent  people.  Usually try to give staff backup.  Fair compensation package with attempt to keep employees healthy.
cons: Financial picture is bleak due to recent purchase of EMR that overburdened the entire company. They had to make draconian cuts which have been made before. As a result, the office staff is at a bare minimum and stress level is high. Prepare to work overtime! HR will always back up management in a conflict!

review_title: Epic PMs and Directors like chickens with heads cut off running around not knowing what's what
pros: Providence core values. Actually very little spews over to my department. That little bit raises our morale up one millimeter per week
cons: Horrible horrible Epic team culture.  Wave 1 or wave whatever, analysts lack respect towards hospital end users. Too much bad mouthing behind the walls towards their very own customers the MDs RNs MAs PAs techs. NOT the Providence way. Hardly any team cohesion, wayyyy overworked analysts, high turnover. Too many holes, mismanaged projects, total chaos. I'm surprised healthcare regulatory bodies haven't  heard of IT mishaps, accidental medical record errors, switcharoos, etc, etc. SERIOUSLY sad

review_title: Providence is a GREAT place to work
job_title: Senior Nursing Recruiter in Portland, OR
pros:
Mission-driven company that  focuses on the poor and the vulnerable.   Forward-thinking and stays ahead of the health care world.  Competitive wages and outstanding benefits.  Fair-minded and keeps the employees engaged by giving us a voice with surveys and conversations.

I have been with Providence for over 7 years as administration and staff.  The one constant with Providence is change, but at the end of the day it is aimed at the good of the people.  I love the company, believe in its mission, and highly recommend as a great place to work.
cons: Change is a constant, but usually for the betterment of the company.

pros: Merging with other hospitals, creating a health care system that ties in with their universal outlook and operation for the health care industry.
cons: Old style management. Nepotism in depts. needs to be disallowed or eliminated, too much politics and favortism, which is detrimental to any organization. Non-Profit ideology with Profit  bearing functions, portrays a PHONY IMAGE, where billing is NOT comparable to competitors in same city for the same hospitalization care.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Lots of nice people. Some are good and smart. Bright office environment. Decent amenities like coffee, team, gym.
cons: There are many people who are not very good at what they do, but stick around because there is no incentive to leave; it's so comfortable & cushion. So if you are a go-getter, chances are you'll be doing a lot of the work, since many will sit around.

review_title: terrible hours and times, pay is low, no benefits, no raises.
pros: For the most part, you get to work with great people in a positive environment, and meet interesting people, and learn a lot during conferences.
cons: Pay is low, hours are evenings and weekends mostly, or covering one of the full-time people when they call in sick or take vacation. No chance of full-time unless one of the FT people leave, which probably won't happen.

job_title: Senior IT Technician in Eureka, CA
pros: Good work/life balance.  Good benefits.  Clear mission and values.  Good pay for the area (though perhaps not so much for other locations).
cons:
I had an opportunity to have a one-on-one phone conversation with the CIO, and he told me very clearly: unless I move to Orangewood, then I have no technical career opportunities with this company.

The IT operation is hyper centralized.  This was done as an overreaction to the decentralized way that each site used to operate.  Centralization of things like the EMR was a very good thing (or at least a good idea, if not hastily and aggressively implemented), but they went overboard.  Along with the EMR they also centralized as much of the rest of the IT infrastructure as they could, including the career opportunities.  These days, if you don't live in Orangewood, CA then you don't have a shot at the higher end IT jobs.  All the remote sites offer are basic grunt work IT jobs.  Even then, a lot of the career employees were laid off and their jobs handed to contractors like Gordian Dynamics.  What's worse is that the central teams show no respect for the IT techs at the remote sites.  We're treated with a lot of disrespect and as if we know nothing.  That pretty closely sums up the state of the IT culture at Saint Joseph: the central teams think that remote sites are full of idiots, and the remote sites think that the central team is full of jerks.

Whether they are overworked, understaffed, or just plain slow and stupid, the central teams move at a snails pace and don't support the remote sites very well.  The hyper centralization puts remote sites in a position where they are entirely dependent on the central teams to deploy configurations or run reports in order for us to do our jobs, but it takes months for them to do anything.  This leads remote site techs to come up with cheap hacks and workarounds.  Many settings that would be best deployed via Group Policy or SCCM are instead configured locally because it's just easier than dealing with the central team attitude, and we at least have the ability to manage it ourselves.

The CIO wants to lead a company like Apple or Facebook.  He's lost sight of the fact that he's ultimately an IT manager, not an innovative software company CEO; but he's running IT in that manner.  He's also a bit too much of a politician (like, he seems accustomed to lying).

Being on-call in IT is legally dubious, because you don't get on-call pay while you're on-call; you only get paid if you actually get called in.  Management claims that this is legal because being on-call is "non restrictive".  We're told that we don't have to respond when getting paged while on-call.  That's an outright lie.  If we're on-call and get paged but don't respond then we will be in trouble.

At the end of the day, my position is just a job, not a career.  I'm better off looking elsewhere to develop myself.

review_title: Overall very good over the 15 years I was th. Quick growth and inexperienced management limited its continued blessings.
pros: In the early years it was its Christian affiliation and the mission; caring senior executives; and experienced caring individuals who believed in that mission that drove the care and compassion employees had for its customers - and for each other. There was a sense of belonging. And the health benefits and wages were above average and employees were able to raise a family without the hardships seemingly placed on so many other employees in other companies. So, employees felt important, they felt valued which led them to exceed the higher standards that the Sisters of Providence had always demanded and been known for.
cons: The org. grew by leaps and bounds in the 90's and on into the 2000's. Management in-experience, competition locally and regionally, plus a faster paced health care environment and the increasingly larger amount of regulation placed on health care helped to erode the excellence within Providence and the feeling of community amoung employees. Eventually, executives and many senior managers caved to the pressure of survival and gave up the goal of being an organization that was all about the patient via. the service and compassionate care provided by the employee.  PH&S gave up on trying to be different, trying to be the one special and unique entity in the community that was about family and its employees. They forgot the importance of the employee who was giving their-all for the organization; they forgot that employees ARE what make the organization and are the soldiers in the trenches and on the front line with the patient/customers, and the thousands of families it touches.Some bad apples and inexperienced management helped continue the downward spiral to what everyone now sees - the New Providence Health and Services.

review_title: Digital Innovation Group - Engaging work, Inspiring vision and Amazing leaders
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros:
I have been working here as a Senior Software Developer for one and half years. These are the things I like about DIG, in order:
- People. Talented bunch of folks to learn from, yet willing to listen to your ideas and brainstorm with you. Motivated and always focused on customer obsession.
- Interesting problem. This is very important to me, keeps me engaged. And, cherry on the top is applying these solution to Healthcare, which badly needs some tech-love. Kudos to Providence for setting some example.
- Career ladder. This was set up in the my first 3 months time at DIG and we had to do some house cleaning to get this in place. I am happy about the bold steps taken. This reflects the leadership interest in growing you. My manager regularly talks what it takes to go to next level and got me a mentor who is a principal engineer.
-  Leadership. This is such a key for organization's growth. They did take some bold step to do some house cleaning and establishing the right culture. When I have joined people were have a relaxed lunch when the production systems have gone down. We have come a long way to establish what it takes to be on the top of customer service.
- Good benefits. Also, tries to match the numbers with these giant Seattle companies.
- Last but not least, the mission. As I mentioned earlier, I am happy to see the application of technology for a bigger good of society.
cons:
DIG is like a startup within Providence, which is very young. One of the cons, I could think of, is the dev-tooling. I have worked at one of these giant tech companies in the past and comparing with them, DIG is on the right path, but has got some distance to cover to reach that maturity.

Looking at the other side of the things - you get a chance to build all those amazing stuff to make dev's life easy.

pros: My coworkers were all great to work with.

review_title: Too much ambiguity and chaos to contribute /make a difference in Shared Services where management is too slow.
pros:
Easy place to work in Renton if you are there for job and doesn't matter if you don't make a difference.

Covert office environment. 
Ambiguity is okay when caused by change, but not when caused by culture of poor ways of managing and leading that cause ambiguity.  too much ambiguity, ie. unclear goals and roles and when asking about that, you can expect a long turn around time to get them answered, which impacts productivity in Shared Services.  Turnaround time of information / decisions from management is exceptionally long leaving workers in rework mode when mgmt. finally gets back to them. 
In 2+ years, never was thanked for all the work done except in mass meetings a few times a year. 
In 2+ years, Director was under big stress the entire time and I did not have a good experience with that. 
Organization does not have a development environment for employees as of 2014 for development in shared services.  I didn't see very many promotions during my time there. (we were told the strategy was inspire and develop, so if they do follow through, things should change finally to where the org will be focused on development, which it needs in healthcare with ways healthcare industry is changing. No more mediocrity.)  
Shared Service offices - benefits reduced as of 2015.
Tried to expand in my area of work, and was limited. 
CEO from Swedish has never managed an organization as big as this across 5 states.
