pros: Rapidly evolving company in a leadership position in the industry.  Tackling the challenges of the industry head-on, engaging new types of skills while retaining the core competencies needed to succeed.  Extraordinary mission focus drives all decisions.
cons: Like all in the industry, Providence is having to adjust dramatically in response to a rapidly developing market.  This is hard.  There is a lot of inertia to be overcome

review_title: Large organization serving all sorts of communities in multi State hospital and health  care.
job_title: Utilization Review Coordinator Nurse in Portland, OR
pros: Advancement encouraged, education prized. You can move around in the different States or areas.  The organization does try to treat every hospital or area of health care as it's own entity.
cons: Large wheels of company can be daunting.  Some of the higher functions of a large company are here. They have regionalized a lot of areas, such as, HR. The time it takes to get small things done can be frustrating.

pros: I've been with Providence for less than 6 months and It was on my short list of target companies in Portland.  Providence is actively adding positions to support the growth of the company.   Work/life balance, benefits, and company culture are strong.  There are lots of changes happening, and they are all for the right reasons.  Team dynamics in my group are healthy without chaos and drama.  Support  from management is beyond my expectations.
cons: Providence is a not-for-profit organization so there are some perks I left behind, such as an annual bonus and a more generous PTO plan.

pros: Good people to work with.  Most managers care about your well being and personal life concerns.
cons: Zero holiday pay.  This comes out of your own PTO.  If you are looking to get a decent raise each year you will need to change job roles every year.  Pay raises, on average, are 2-3%.

pros: The company has a great mission and values. I've been with the company over 5 years and have met some of my good friends through this company.  The people kept me staying because most of the people I run across are genuine caring people who care for their patients and their coworkers.
cons: My current manager could use better coaching and leadership skills to develop the staff to their full potential.  Staff meetings and 1:1s aren't as engaging or productive and I personally feel the meetings are there to make sure everyone is still alive and have some coworkers talk just to be heard.  My team hasn't met it's numbers in at least 3 months and I wouldn't be surprised if it was longer.  This isn't because my team and I are bad at what we do but the expectations are too high.  My team have lost seniors because they are under utilizing them and most of us are burnt out and are still expected to go full blast on our job duties.   This job is an marathon and not a sprint.

pros: Medical Benefits are not too bad.  Premiums are low and we get a health incentive which is $700 for individual and $1,400 for employee+ children.
cons: Leadership No longer follows the mission, holidays come out of your PTO.  We are Understaffed and underpaid.  Raises this year doesn’t even cover the cost of living!  The longer you’ve been here, the less you get.

pros: You will meet amazing people that will stick with you for life. Decent health insurance.
cons:
You receive a lot of PTO but you also have to use it for your holidays.

The management needs a complete overhaul they treat every examiner different. They pit the examiners against the auditors supervisor doesn’t have your back when it comes to rebuttals. 

Extremely low pay for the amount of work required 
No growth potential once your in claims you’re stuck 

Old dos system

pros: Inspired by the mission and have wonderful coworkers. After three years, and again at five years, pto is increased.
cons: Pto is all inclusive - sick/vacation/holidays. Major changes ongoing throughout each group and no opportunity for advancement without changing groups; hard to "move up". Medical benefits are very poor for a healthcare company. Minimal choices with no options for care anywhere near main offices.

review_title: A big organization with a strong mission
pros: A strong mission to provide healthcare to the poor and vulnerable, a set of values that inform most decisions, fantastic physicians, mid-level providers and other caregivers (all employees are 'caregivers'), job stability, ability to transfer to other locations, the resources of a large organization, strong research and innovation focus, learning and growth opportunities if you seek it out.
cons: Large organizations have communication struggles and Providence is no different. Sometimes impacted department leaders/caregivers find out about changes when the whole system does. Underperforming caregivers can take time to move along due to the conservative discipline process after the 90-day probationary period.

pros: I love it when patients feel they are cared for and important. My Co-workers make the job fun and interesting. We work as a team to care for the patients.
cons: We need new upper management. They are distant and removed from the daily concerns that affect staff and patients. There is very strong fear of retaliation if any one raises concerns.

review_title: Great people with great values, management seems to be stuck and inefficient
pros:
The people you work with are great - values, culture, work ethic.
Everyone is very friendly and helpful, from System office into the various hospitals. 
The employees generally have better ethics and values than many in management and executive levels.
cons:
Executives and management don't 'walk their talk' which can be frustrating.
Some departments are undergoing extensive and haphazard restructuring - IT and other system office level departments.

review_title: The company as a whole has vastly been improving facilities and how we treat patients over the years.
pros: They have a tuition reinbursement program and as a student, I found that to be especially helpful. Though, it only covers $2000, so if you went to a university like I did, it won't cover everything, but that is still a free $2000.
cons: In my department, the management is outsourced from a different company. I'm not entirely sure if this is the case across the board, but it does put a damper on internal development, ie: "moving up the ladder".

pros: Providence is very mission-oriented and all decisions are viewed through a lens of being beneficial to all potential patients.
cons: Swedish is allowed to operate with many different policies and there is little connection between the two companies, which is a big miss.  Many employees have been with the organization for a long time or are very late in their careers, which leads to a disconnect with younger employees and new strategies in favor of "tried and true," but very paper-heavy, antiquated processes.

pros:
Great organization of people
Mission is center
Quality Care
Efforts to keep up with changing times/ways (innovation)
Did I say People??
Ever evolving...

I have been an employee here for 6 years and I have had a great career trajectory. I started at one of the lowest paying positions in the organization while in school completing a degree. It took some time to transition from the role that I had held while educating myself into a role that was more fitting for my ambitions, talents, and abilities. This is where I think that we have some room for growth as an organization. 
Once someone decided to take a chance on me, the rest was history, and it has been great. 
There has been a gap of valuable development of talent at the lower levels, but I can see that there is a shift that began in the last 2 years. It emphasizes growing our own talent. We are a big organization and the cultural shift to have core leaders realize that there are diamonds in the rough right here that only need a bit of buffering in order to shine is permeating through the system. I believe that this is key to maintaining such a great organization, because it brings meaningful conversations between our caregivers and leaders. This will help us to keep these great people that makeup such a caring culture that is true to the mission.
cons:
Top Heavy
Lots of managers
Ever evolving...

review_title: Widespread  morale issues in the coding department. (See Cons )
pros: Great benefits, overall good company. They are reassessing the production standard, and hopefully will come up with a reasonable outcome. If so, I would give Providence a 5-star rating!
cons: Current Problems with recently (1 year) implemented production  standards are creating widespread morale issues within the coding department.>

review_title: Poor management prevent a great customer experience
pros: People in other departments are nice and respectful towards their fellow co-workers in other departments. Doctors are nice and treat other staff (pharmacists, nurses, CNAs, etc) with respect.
cons:
Management here is terrible! Often times pharmacy management will ask you to do their jobs for them (apparently it's pharmacy staff's responsibility to arrange for coverage if someone calls out sick on top of all other responsibilities). Every other place I have worked, you told a manager if someone called off sick and they would take care of it, but here whoever gets the call has to also find someone to cover or the person who answered the call will get in trouble (for not doing the manager's job for them).

Pharmacy management will also take all the credit for great work by pharmacy without giving any credit to the staff who did all the real work. Management is only concerned about numbers, so if there's fewer patients who are more sick (who still require more care), they will think it's not busy (and they can just flex people off), but if there's a lot of patients who aren't that sick they will keep staffing levels. 

Medications are frequently out of stock because people don't do their job (not necessarily due to the nationwide drug shortages), but management doesn't seem to care (especially if it's a weekend or at night). People come in late and don't start working soon after come (they clock in and eat a leisurely breakfast or chit-chat for 20 or 30 minutes while the work piles up and the phones are ringing off the hook), but management doesn't seem to care about this.

People who work during the day get a lot of praise and free meals and other gifts, but if you work in the evening or at night, management doesn't care about you and gives you no praise. Even during pharmacy appreciation week, management  told us "you can eat the leftovers of what we gave to to the daytime people," as if we are dogs on the street.

pros: The best and most cohesive team I ever worked with in 35 years of nursing.
cons:
Although individual management styles obviously vary, my direct manager focused on rigidly adhering to her own agenda and implemented programs without involving staff members. Any student of change theory knows that creating buy in from those affected by a proposed change is essential. Staff concerns were ignored and it was clear that a great deal of favoritism was directed toward some individuals. Many of my colleagues expressed great dissatisfaction with the management style but, unfortunately there was no mechanism to provide her supervisors with an anonymous evaluation of her performance.

As someone with many years of experience, a higher level of education than my manager, and a reluctance to do things "because we do them", I felt that there was a concerted effort to find reasons to terminate my employment. Being at the top of the pay scale and not accepting "rules" if I felt that they were not in an individual patients best interest, There was no room for any nurse's individual professional judgement about actions if it was felt to not adhere to a "rule". I clearly became a less desirable employee than a nurse with less experience who questions less. Demonstration of age discrimination are often difficult to prove. I feel that this was a definite issue in my relationship with my manager.  

Providence has  admirable sounding statements of goals and mission. Unfortunately, this philosophy is frequently absent or poorly applied to patient care. It was not uncommon for fellow staff members to make very negative comments about patients and their visitors. This often caused less than compassionate care to be delivered without any repercussions for the staff members. Staff discipline focused on rather trivial issues like being 1-2 minutes late for report (which typically did not start for several minutes after that time). The mission and goals were completely ignored in regards to staff concerns. Your job was to show up, shut your mouth, and slavishly follow directions. 

Staffing levels throughout the hospital were too low for the acuity of the patients cared for. I can"t speak to specialty areas, but the loads required for staff in general patient care areas were often dangerous and unsafe. There was no mechanism available to document or report staff concerns. 

Many staff members had skills and knowledge that could benefit their colleagues if a formal structure was in place to share it. The area where I worked had great learning needs that some staff members could easily provide. These important resources were not utilized, which was a great waste of resources.

review_title: Mission Statement does not apply to employees
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Portland, OR
pros: Competitive wages, lots of areas to work.
cons: Benefits and retirement have been stripped down to a disgusting low.  I could get better Providence insurance through another employer, rather than my employee policy.   The focus is solely on money, oh, and their sports park , and while they talk a good game, they definitely do NOT “Know me, care for me, ease my way”.

pros:
1) You can work from home
2) Starting pay is exactly average
3) You work for a non-profit with moral values
cons:
I think it is best just to list them:

1) Took 2 months to get a laptop - this seems like the norm
2) Still not on all the email list serves after a year
3) Laptop provided lacks adequate specs to run Epic
4) Direct manager decided to not meet with me for 2-3 months, not one single point of contact and she no-showed to every meeting
4) Every deployment is behind schedule
5) Service Now was rolled out as the new change control software, but some sites still did not have access for weeks after go-live
6) Constantly find systemic issues from past site deployments and there is no form of Root Cause Analysis and resolution to prevent issues from happening. Some of these issues are legitimate patient safety issues that go unnoticed. 
7) There is a complex set of aggressive company politics at play - for example, one analyst for a deployment missed a minor deadline by a few days and one of the C-Suite of the site expressed extremely negative feedback. Learned that the individual has been pushing for the delay of the project. See the Exer go-live as an example: The whole project was scrapped weeks before go-live, Exer departments still in Production and all. 
8) When I joined, there were an extremely large of unaddressed, un-viewed break-fix incidents in the system for our team (400-500+)
9) There is a lack of a governance structure. Both clinicians and IT staff alike do not know where to take issues or requests to get approval. For example, apparently there are "idea" tickets with an associated approval process for large systemic change requests, but there is no evidence on how to submit these or who approves them or any information at all really.
10) No training at all, but frankly it was not needed
11) Team meetings regularly turn into yelling matches and are just far too uncomfortable to attend. 
12) I was kicked out of my office since it was being sold no replacement 
13) The IT department is 2.2 billion dollars in deficit 

No comment on job advancement/raises.

pros: Co workers and how we helped each other cope with the stressors of work. A supportive union that promotes fairness and works hard to support staff/nurses and protect against corporate greed.
cons: A toxic work environment. They talk the talk when it comes to bullies, but management seems to promote the experienced and turn them loose to bully. Even the well educated are bullies. Don't understand this culture and why it is allowed, but it has increased 10 fold over the 8 years my my rein until I finally had enough and left.

review_title: The company has changed so much after the Epic implementation
pros: The health insurance use to be really excellent as well as paid time off.  Both of those were recently changed.  Still good insurance compared to other companies.
cons: Providence has gotten too big and forgot about the staff who support the mission and core values.  Now everything and decisions have to be made at a system level and takes forever to get things accomplished.

pros: This position allows you to work with patients daily and see all departments of the hospital.  Requires minimal education and training.  Great job for entry level healthcare minded people.
cons: Little to no room for advancement.  It is a job not a career if that makes sense.  Become almost routine or robotic after a few years and the compensation is not inline with the work load and stress.

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Olympia, WA
pros: I have worked for Providence for 10 years and it is the best job I have ever had.  I get to work with a team of Speech Therapists, PTs and OTs who are knowledgeable, professional and compassionate from whom I have learned so much.  When I have a problem, I have a very approachable supervisor who responds to my concerns.  The work that I do here nourishes me emotionally, cognitively, and spiritually.
cons: In the past, I have had supervisors that were not responsive to my concerns, but it is quite perfect now.

pros: Friendly environment, good leadership (mostly). Perfect value system and motto.
cons: Pay isn't too competitive, and its more difficult to climb within the company than they make you think.

job_title: RN Clinical Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros: Volume of jobs available, locations throughout the area. Decent pay ranges.
cons: Do not care about their employees, terrible culture. HR does not take discrimination, bullying or harassment complaints seriously. Benefits are disappointing compared to other healthcare organizations. Lack of part time RN jobs make it hard to have a family and continue to working for them.

pros: Great benefits, mostly great people to work with, flexible schedules, central location, the trick is getting on the right team that empowers their staff.
cons: Management seems to be less and less concerned with well being of staff. Lots of negative turnover and occasional lay offs. Many people quitting managers, not the organization. Downsizing has made it more difficult to move positions within the company.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Medford, OR
pros: The experience I received from them was just what I needed in my first job of my health care career. I learned and meet the most amazing people. All the people I interacted with inside Providence were extremely kind and caring.
cons:
Politics. 
Same with every big  organization.

review_title: Disconnect between Senior Management and Line Employees
pros: Providence pays well at the System Office but there is definitely a price to pay for this in that your personal life will take a back seat to getting the job done - at least for people on the front line of service.
cons: Middle management does not understand the time needed to complete the job. People on the front line end up working overtime (sometimes without reporting it) in order to complete their work.

pros: Good PTO, most leaders are good to work for and have your back, great co-workers, mission and values.  The benefits are good, but not as good as other healthcare employers.
cons: If you're salary, knock your hourly pay rate you're making by 20-30%.  Senior leadership = margin.  Pay is below market in some places (especially Oregon).

pros: The people at providence overall do a good job of walking the walk of supporting the mission to help the poor and vulnerable. I've never worked at a company before which had so many good, honest hard-working people.
cons: The downside to an organization of this size is that there is a lot of constant reorganizing and lots of red tape. It's takes a really long time to see actionable results because dozens of teams and people need to weigh in on everything. It can get exhausting,

review_title: Digital Innovation Group - not a great place for software developers
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: - DIG team norms are great in helping to create a good work culture. Not enough to help DIG grow as a technology group though.
cons:
- Poor diversity and inclusion.

- This is a management heavy technology group within a very large not-for-profit company.  Too many decision makers lead to slow growth.

- Development managers on software teams are not required to have core knowledge and experience, which is unhealthy for the team and product. 

- A large part of the group was recently shut down within 2-3 years of the group's formation.

- Salaries are not at par with current market pay levels.

pros: This is a large organization and there are many ways the organization can innovate.
cons: Company values were not part of my work group, especially, "We nurture the spiritual, emotional and physical well-being of one another". Behind closed doors, COO frequently criticized current and past employees. Group was competitive in an unconstructive way. There was obvious favoritism on the part of management and executive team. The best performers were rewarded even though they did not embody company values.

pros: Team's culture. Everyone is willing to share best practices and share candidates if they are a better fit for a position that they are not recruiting for. Great family benefits and a year round bus pass for all employees (regardless of FTE).
cons: The Talent Acquisition team is growing so fast it is hard to get the opportunity to get to know all colleagues.

pros: Benefits are great, and well-priced for employee and family. Shifts are reasonable, and usually able to pick up OT or extra shifts when needed
cons: Communication breakdown between management and staff. Very strict attendance policy. Unable to clock in even 1 MINUTE late. If you clock in more than 1 minute late a handful of times, you are reprimanded. Parking can be tricky

pros: Great people to work with
cons: Hyper growth causing concern as they outsource and offshore core business functions like talent acquisition and AP as well as others. If I hadn't moved to a different location/role I would have been out of a job!

job_title: MRI Technologist in Oregon City, OR
pros: Skilled peers and good Pay and benefits.
cons: Lack of vision and inability to implement best business practices. Decisions made in a box, real world, real time decisions and opinions ignored. Slow response time to pandemic, with inadequate PPE.

review_title: Company big on "integrity" but light on delivery of what we preach
pros: good mission and vision.  Employees are good
cons: inconsistency in delivery of integrity issues.  Management plays mind games and some upper managers have very big ego needs.  Advancement is dependent on gamesmanship as much as delivery of results.

pros: Great employees who are really trying to make a difference. Newer management is bringing in fresh ideas!  Great focus on mission and vision. Lots of progress in the last 4 years.
cons: Worked in Missoula, MT.  Older institution so hard to implement change. Executive level management is like a good ol' boys club and lack the guts to communicate or even make tough decisions.  They get rid of people who buck the norm rather than listening to new perspectives.

pros: I love that most people here really care about the Mission & Core Values.  The top leaders are top notch, and care about developing their staff.  They care about the organization and the patients we serve.  There is a lot of information about the initiatives Prov is doing if you know how to find it.    A lot of people are willing to help if you ask.
cons:
It is a big organization. There are no paid holidays (which hourly staff must take), so the PTO bank appears to be better than it is.  The annual review process doesn't let staff get more than ~2.5% unless others in the department get less (and 2.5% is really inflation-proofing, not much of a merit increase).  A couple of years ago everyone got a flat 1.5%.  

Do not expect to ever negotiate your salary once you start.  I was offered a new position after many years, and when I went to negotiate was essentially told by HR a week later to "take it or leave it" and was told there were other candidates they would move on to if I didn't decide within the hour.  There were no other candidates!  I know others who have had a similar experience, or who have just not negotiated.

A lot of line staff are comfortable doing their job the same way they always have, or according to policies that sometimes don't make sense anymore.  

Information about how PH&S is doing isn't communicated well, and how decisions are made is not well understood.  Too many new initiatives without realistic goals make many just ignore them as the newest flavor of the week.  Sometimes leaders just like talking to leaders and don't really want to involve line staff in meaningful conversations.

review_title: They always try to do the right thing
job_title: Senior Lead Recruiter in Seattle, WA
pros: Thoughtful, inclusive, and caring that always wants to do the right thing.  The company is full of people that are hard working and patient centered.
cons: Meeting heavy; slow to take action with prevents innovation in a timely manner, but then will move quickly on things and fall short of communication, which can cause heartburn for people quickly.  They have grown so much and it's hard for any company to stay up with communication plans when they have grown as fast as they have.

review_title: Very Corporate, slow approval processes, highly paid tenured employees threaten new employees
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
This review is strictly on the business operations side. As far as the clinical side of things I cannot speak of.

Great work life balance, Providence is a healthcare giant, so things move at very slow pace where their are very few urgent deadlines to be met. You have ample time to complete job duties. Minimal supervision if any (can be a pro or con). Must be able to self manage, self create and self implement. For for the most part employees are happy as the company does not create a high pressure work environment, but at the same time if you need something done quickly, good luck! High salaries compared to the market for the business operations jobs. Great benefits on the Medical Dental Vision side of things, the retirement plan is lacking.
cons: A lot of silo'ed employees, working in their own bubble. This could be attributed to segmented department structures and locations. Minimal "team" feel. Due to the self manage atmosphere processes are not defined, you will get different answers from employees. Due to the high salaries there are a lot of tenured employees who have been their for 10+ 15+ years. They are very cautious of new employees and will complain to management if they feel their job could be threatened down the road. You will be looked down upon for trying to speed up or simplify processes by current staff, as the so called 'complicated' processes they use to protect their worth to the company. Very lax work environment (could be pro or con) which effects the overall company's bottom numbers. It is more about who you know and who you can befriend than how hard you work. Actually working too hard could work against you. Slow approval processes, which is half due to the large corporate structure and half due to the fact employees take their time to get things done.

job_title: RN, Trauma Coordinator in Walla Walla, WA
pros: Excellent CNO, caring staff, good health insurance and  great physicians. At the ministry level, there is a strong commitment to the community.
cons: PSMMC is well managed and profitable. Other ministries within the Providence System are not. Rather than allowing PSMMC to make needed improvements, any funds considered in excess is used to support other ministries. We share a CEO with a ministry in a neighboring city. The loss of a full-time CEO is felt at the bedside level. Many of us feel that we are no longer well represented in the system.

job_title: Senior IT Technician in Eureka, CA
pros:
Good pay/benefits for where I live.
Local team is excellent.
cons:
Regular layoffs (at least two big ones per year).
Extremely top heavy management.
No advancement opportunity without relocation.
Poor communication between remote teams.
Incompetent central teams.
A history of bad IT leadership on the St. Joes side.

review_title: Seems like a great place to work; it’s not.
job_title: Accounts Receivable Specialist in Portland, OR
pros:
-Good benefits without long wait period to qualify
-Flexible schedule: able to set your start time w/managers approval, ie: 6a, 7a or 8a etc.
cons:
-High claims expectations - Expects you to work on over 100 claims per day

-Dark and dreary office was a windowless cubicle world. You spend all your time on the computer and phone calls. It’s like a call center job.

-Training, although it felt thorough, did not prepare employees for the variety of claims problems encountered. New employees were trying to help each other problem solve without guidance.

-Doctor’s Note not accepted for illnesses - Providence utilizes a 3rd party to “verify” if an absence is “excused” or “unexcused”. Not understanding this, I brought in a doctor’s note after an illness only to be told my absence was still considered unexcused. Shortly after this my treatment by management took a turn for the worse. It led to a very toxic environment because I had an “unexcused” absence in my first 3 months of employment. It was so toxic in fact, I had to resign because I was becoming physically ill from the stress.

-Restrictions on advancement opportunities— you aren’t allowed to apply for other opportunities within the company for certain periods of time. Ie: you have to be in a position for a year or two before you’re allowed to transfer elsewhere within the company.

-Parking is VERY limited - the later you start in the morning the less places there are to park and some folks couldn’t get parking at all.

-Values disconnect - Providence was trying to improve employee health by banning sodas/soft drinks, yet they sold ice cream, muffins, cookies,  fruit juices, candy, etc., an array of food/drink items which easily exceeded the sugar content of the banned sodas. 

-Pep-Rallies were mandatory - once a month all employees were required to attend a pep rally of sorts at the nearby cancer center’s auditorium. This was required but not useful to employees. It was meant to build solidarity but felt like a waste of time because we didn’t learn anything new to help us improve our work or our relationships with our colleagues. 

-Employee health wasn’t very helpful - while running a fever one day I ran down to employee health. They confirmed the fever but told me to take a Tylenol and sent me back to work. This was the start of a severe flu they failed to recognize.

-Lots of hoops to jump through to onboard  - there were several appointments at different locations required to onboard. Blood labs and drug screens were required, vaccines, photo for the ID badge, paperwork completion, etc. all at different facilities and offices, and thus a lot of running around required simply to be set up in the system as an employee.

review_title: Great place to work to be the catalyst to help Humanity!
job_title: Senior Technical Recruiter in Renton, WA
pros:
I have been a recruiter for 21 years, having worked as a 3rd party agency recruiter for 20 years.  Working at Providence as a Senior Recruiter is the first time I have worked internally.  Working for a faith- based non-profit is quite different than working in the for-profit corporate world…and this is a good thing. Providence is all about the mission to help humanity.  I am not a doctor and I am not an engineer but I think I am a pretty decent Recruiter.  It is very motivating to me to know what I am recruiting folks who are utilizing Big Data technology to do predictive analytics to find cures for chronic illnesses such as cancer, diabetes and heart disease.  If I recruit someone who ends up providing a certain bit of data that finds the cure for cancer for instance, I will have great satisfaction in knowing that I may have been the catalyst in helping out in that process.  It is great to be a productive part of something that is bigger than myself. 
     Providence is a great place to work!  We have true work-life balance here.  You will not get financially rich working here like you may working in a for-profit software company.  However, we do pay fairly for the work you do here and the benefits are fantastic!  Folks who want as much money as possible need to go work for Amazon, Microsoft or other software firms dejour.  Then when you burn out from all the long hours you work and the stress that the job demands and you have to then pay for a resulting divorce you may realize that the more modest pay you will get at Providence is more in line with the stress-free life that you deserve.  I work an honest 40 to 45 hour work week with a team that is very friendly and supportive.  I have worked in a for profit environment before and I have already ridden the financial and emotional roller-coaster….I decided I had enough and I am now blessed to work here at Providence.  There are folks who work here that are in their mid 20s to mid 60s in age and are all very mature.  There are no cliques, very professional folks who are motivated by supporting our mission to help the poor and the vulnerable. I am in my 40s now and I only wish I had realized sooner the benefits of working here when I was in my 30s.
cons: Does not pay as well as for profit organizations do.  However, if you are at a point in your life where you can scale back a bit on compensation in return for a better work/life balance and far less stress then this is the place for you!

pros: Best supervisors in this department, ever! Employees are important to this management team. This position helps patients in financial need.
cons: The wages have typically been much lower than other healthcare providers. The employee health care plan has so much out of pocket costs that many employees don't seek treatment when they should.

review_title: Awesome place to work, great work-life balance, creative and positve collaborations
pros:
In my experience as a new employee, my journey from the beginning to my third week has been remarkable. I think the best reason to work for Providence Health & Services is that I am proud to be part of the Providence family for the things that they do for the community.
There are more, but here are the key points of what I observed so far:
1)	The organization treats the employees with respect by welcoming the uniqueness of each individual. This is more than just the Equal Employment Opportunity in writing. You can still be yourself doing what you do best for the organization. I've seen some cubicles decorated with Pokemon, Godzilla, Seahawk, Star Wars, you name it. You will feel like home so quickly. I feel that I don’t have to try hard to fit in because I felt a warm welcome from my peers regardless my look, my race or ethnic.
2)	The organization provides health and saving benefits, and also the commuter benefits. As someone who came from out of the state, this is a huge benefit. There is also a benefit for carpooling or bicycling to work. For me, I just love my ORCA to get me to places easily and independently than driving on my own – parking can be a headache. There are more benefits for commuter that I mentioned here though. Speaking about benefits, I love having the gym in the headquarter buildings with shower.
3)	There are plenty of mission driven non-profit organizations out there, but providence walks the talks in everything. I just love how the organization promotes volunteerism that benefits the community. One of many examples, Providence does not just do gardening to beautify the buildings, but to donate the harvest to the community.
4)	The recruiter treats the candidate with compassion even when the applied position after position did not work out in the candidate's favor. The recruiter keep in-touch and connects the candidate with other recruiters in different areas of the candidate's interests. In addition to this, the recruiter even follow-up to see if the candidate is doing okay in the job search journey. In my case, this was the team manager. Nowadays, there are only a few recruiters I’ve met that recruit with empathy.
5)	The department I am part of always collaborate with others for improvement opportunity. This is aligned with my belief that change is the only thing permanent (by philosopher Heraclitus). There are plenty of resources accessible to learn on my own too. Also, do you ever eat a cookie with a code scanner to a thank you video? I love how creative is the department as they promote creative thinking in their works.
6)	The team manager that I am part of, she welcomed me at our first meeting with a hug and warm greetings. She made sure I have everything I need to get started using a tool to guide me through my first 3 weeks. I am not talking about the office supplies, but the required information, the resources, and learning communities to equip me for success in my role.
cons: I really did not see anything that I feel disappointed about. Providence motivates me to wake up very early to catch the bus/train and still feel so excited to be at work.

pros: SJO has the best work environment I have ever had the opportunity to be a part of.  The mission and values are real.  You see them every day.  People care about each other.  You can feel in when you walk into the place.  Opportunities to learn and grow are all over the place.
cons: Parking needs to be better.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Denver, CO
pros: Loved working with my colleagues. We just knew how to help each other, never gave up when the tough days saw little light and at the end, we'd be back with each other the next day to support and be there.
cons: HR did not find me a job at my value when I was injured, but offered me an entry level position outside of my educational background. I did not take it. They let me go. One of my closest colleagues also experienced a similar situation.

review_title: Registered nurses are the life-blood of cost-effective health care; skilled professionals providing value-added service.
job_title: STaff Registered Nurse in Portland, OR
pros: since they are a large non-profit corporation that has operations in at least 7 states in the west, there are many opportunities within the system for those who would like to stay with providence.  they have a good reputation for their quality of health care in general; many patients and providers choose Providence due to this reputation, and they are happy to be there when they start.  The employees within the hospital - nurses, doctors, transportation techs, housekeepers, etc. - most of them see themselves as integral to a positive care experience for each patient.  Teamwork and the rapport with my colleagues was the major factor keeping me there.
cons: although administration speaks of the mission, calling Providence a Ministry, rather than a non-profit corporation, they often do not live up to this rhetoric at the level of the patient.  As a nurse in acute care, it was consistently conveyed to us that we were simply a workforce like any other - we were a financial liability to the work of Providence rather than a value-added service.  In the past 1.5 years, they removed Jesus from the mission statement; this isn't a religious point of contention for me, but I feel it symbolizes a distinct change in upper leadership within the organization.  for acute care registered nurses, Providence offers the worst retirement benefits in the state of oregon.

review_title: Narrow view of health, where people are dehumanized to numbers and treated like nuisances.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Rosa, CA
pros: Great health benefits. Hospital uses electronic medical records.
cons: In my department, staff were overworked and treated poorly. Throughout the hospital, most staff seemed frantic and stressed. Patient care suffered. Interdepartmental communication and cooperation was not very good, and sometimes hostile. I was never afraid of hospitals until I worked here.

review_title: Meh - Very Average Overall; Just Another Stepping Stone for Me
job_title: Clinical Database Analyst in Burbank, CA
pros: The people are super, great to work with. The company has "core values" which I believe were embraced by staff at all levels and not just used as filler material in employee handouts. The cafeteria food was pretty good imo though I am more forgiving than most. There were fun things like swag at training sessions, get-togethers after meetings, etc. Staff was always on board for initiatives and very team oriented and supportive so you could do your job. Training was good as far as I was concerned.
cons: Communication was at times nonexistent. To say that is was "pee poor" would even be an erroneous statement and being a very detailed person I don't want to be off base here. Salary was sub standard also though to be fair the other benefits such as insurance and retirement contributions were above average. To give you an idea I walked out the door and gave myself over a 30% increase in income and that's not counting another job that I didn't get but interviewed for that was even more. You may also have to move up north to work with the technology you desire. There was a lot of personnel change that impacted others much more than me. There is favoritism and bias that can work against you if you are on the wrong side of it.

job_title: Telephones, Scheduling Etc''''' in Portland, OR
pros: When I started over six years ago benefits were great and so was the work atmosphere.
cons:
Than there were lies about how our work was not improving after the Epic go live.  That is where the changes really showed up.  The more dependable, honest, caring workers were flat out being lied about.  There were many that I knew that were let go for various reasons.  There were less experienced workers who did not do the work and delegated to the more experienced detailed worker so they could look good.  Managers were not doing their jobs.  They were told about what was going on and how the newer energetic workers were lying, cheating, backing other employees and not others.  There was a whole different set of rules for some workers and not others. The experienced, longer time, employees left and in some cases forced out of their jobs.  For money and profit, yet Providence has it's name on the new soccer field and upper management never had to give up their jobs and take so much less.  The training for Epic was four half days and go live.  Than after being on line for less than three days I was told I was too slow.  That there was a consideration of letting me go even at that point. It was a horrible experience for a lot of us even some that made it.  

Dependable, caring people were forced out all over the company.  I wish those who can to tell their story.  I know of at least 12 to 15 employees this happened to.  I am sure that is just a few compared to how many there really are.

How sad that this happened to such a good group of harder workers. Customer service is timed now and if you spend more than 2 and a half minutes , on average on the telephone they encourage you to leave and make it difficult to work there.  I can not understand that where some employees downright don't do the work and leave the work for others to do, get the good times on the telephone and look good.  It is awful.

pros: Great opportunity to penetrate into the healthcare field.   Plenty of internal job growth if you remain persistent.  The region is conducting a market analysis to respond to disgruntled employees (compensation).
cons: Residual effect of cost reduction work (2-3 years ago), employee burnout/change fatigue, anemic compensation (not keeping up with cost of living).   Disconnection between executives and line employees...(Leadership is working on this)

pros: Executive Time Off Program - don't accrue PTO, just take time off when you need it
cons: Lack of sophistication, personally and professionally.  Very much a working class organization. Many of the executives don't have formal education.  They just to the top through seniority.  In fact, the non-clinical areas of the organization are very much run like a union where seniority is golden.  Try competing with someone who has been with the organization for 30 years.

pros: Some co-workers made it tolerable.
cons: I had to quit to save my sanity. Cliques are rampant and obviously work to shut others out. No opportunity for growth unless you are part of a (lower) 30-something clique with less than 7-years of experience.  They promote who they like regardless of who can actually do the job. Weak middle-management leadership. Many of the them are completely two-faced and act so arrogant as though you should be happy to be in their presence.  I've never seen so many fake people in my life.  You'd think they worked for Apple because the attitudes are so big.

job_title: Accounts Receivable Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: People where nice to work with Benefits where ok if you didn't have to use them. Pto will only cover for the holidays.
cons: Not enough training. Production is all they cared about. Was fired after came back from FMLA. They will write you up for being 1 minute late to work. If your stuck behind a car wreck was told that I should have planned for that. Supervisors don't know how to even process a claim. Most where there because they had a 4 year degree.

pros: On paper, their mission is good.

Information Services has the most toxic culture of any place I ever worked. We had several major leadership changes over the span of about 18 months.
Each change has somehow brought in leadership that is more thin-skinned and spiteful than the last.
There is no opportunity for career advancement. There is also no expectation of performance.
Reviews are a joke and 1:1s are simply an opportunity for plattitudes. There is no attempt to hire knowledgable people because leadership simply doesn't care.

Current Employee at Providence Medical Center HOLY CROSS

cons: - Management implements some interventions that are HCAHPS oriented rather than Staff and Patient focused. This is inevitable with healthcare. The interventions are not as bad as other hospitals that require a union in order to have staff voices heard.

pros: Excellent staff, mission spirit, supportive, family.
cons: Too big.  Corporate focused, loss of mission goals.  Every "new" initiative is sighted for short term goals or rewards to C-suite.  Shallow support for staff, no rounding, and no visibility, uses “us” and “them” when addressing management and staff.  CEO Med staff is weak with Physicians, everything breaks down at that level because he will not hold them accountable.  CNO, waste of time!

pros: company benefits are great
cons: The company can keep people around too long. People that have checked out. They forget that they want to continuously improve the system and let employees get too comfortable and the CEO/Administration stops challenging them to put their best foot forward. Staff can start to let things go by the way side because of the this and it hurts the people PH&S serves.

pros:
-There are some talented peers and caregivers here. 
-Flex time off for senior leaders is a nice design even though none of the leaders can make use of it. 
-Some caregivers, mostly clinicians, practice the mission and values in their daily work. 
-Gym in Renton is nice. Other places not so much. 
-HQ is located in a semi-convenient commute location as compared with dense downtown locations with other local corporate giants.
cons:
-Careful taking a position here in 2019 or beyond. Plenty of layoffs and reduction in force are happening and planned as the system progresses through the next strategic plan. Don't quit that other organization just yet unless you're taking a critical patient facing position. 
-Core values for top executives are simple window-dressing values with lip service from the top down. These values have little discernible impact on either how Providence caregivers behave or how the organization operates. Most line caregivers are unfortunately sharing this lack a resonance with the mission and values as many are smart enough to see this lip service for what it is. 
-Poor strategy and execution from top leaders in the system resulting in poor performance.  Providence can't sustain the current margins so drastic changes will be in the future for Providence for years to come. 
-Company is still struggling through the merger with St. Joseph Health with little benefit seen to either. 
-Compensation is still very much on the low end to at most, mid-market. This is attributed of course to the non-profit status, but don't believe that for one minute. We are absolutely a for-profit organization hiding behind our tax status.
-Work/life balance is more akin to say Amazon. Expect 60+ hour work weeks to stay caught up, let alone get ahead around here.  
-Talented workers don't stay for long. See above for a few reasons. Many of us are actively looking. 
-Most shared service functions are ineffective and their design contributes to a lack of accountability at all levels of the organization.

review_title: Corporate-feeling, large, system with work to do & good pay
